I sat in the kitchen waiting for her to ask me. As she put down her work bag and took off her coat, I could see that she looked unhappy. I knew she was aware of what was happened but could sense the anxiety of having to ask me.
She looked up at me, eyes already filling up with tears and asked me "You spent all night with him again didn't you?"
I met her gaze but quickly looked away in guilt, looking down at the floor as I replied "Yes."
Tears started flowing from her eyes as she put her hands on her head, as if she was losing grip on her reality. "What is it he has that I don't?"
I played with my fingers anxiously, knowing she wouldn't like the answer I'd give. I sighed and answered "He has a Crowbar and a HEV suit"

She slammed her hands on the table knocking a lukewarm bowl of soup over me, splattering my face as she yelled "What does any of that even mean?!"

I wiped some of the soup off my face using my hand. I took a soup covered finger into my mouth and scraped it off, tasting it.

"Mmmm soup"

I then spent another night playing Half Life 2 as she packed her bags and left for her mothers.

[h2]Half-Life 2 is a great game from the golden era of gaming [/h2]

Disclaimer: This review is based on my first time playing Half-life 2 and Episodes 1/2
 I will be reviewing them as a complete package

Pros+ Cons-
+ Simple FPS gameplay with a decent amount of challenge (and three difficulties)
- Low ammo caps for weapons and high damage taken makes combat is about resource management
+ level design that does a decent job of pointing you in the right direction and explaining puzzles
- It's not always clear where to go and you can overlook things in the environment
+ Entertaining story with great characters and fantastic lore/world building 
- The ending is a cliffhanger unfortunately (Half-Life 3 when?)
+ 2000's era movie style soundtrack with familiar Source Engine sound effects
- Voice audio is often too quiet (There are full captions however)
+ Thanks to the 20th anniversary update we now have workshop support 
   (Download the mod "Barney replaced with Barney The Dinosaur" and have some laughs)

Considering that this game released in 2004...
I didn't encounter a single glitch, crash, or soft-lock.
I know it doesn't necessarily have all of the quality of life and polish that some newer games can have.
However, you would have a hard time finding as great of an experience as this with a lot of modern games.

The influence of Half-Life 2 on the games industry cannot be disputed. Even after 20 years, the gameplay and the visuals hold up very well, now running beautifully on low-end hardware. Every aspect of the game is meticulously crafted to engage the player and propel the story. Even with the plethora of modern options in the genre, this classic is worth a first look for gamers who may have missed it and another look for those who played through years ago.

It also cannot be disputed that, even after 20 years, Half-Life 2 is incomplete. The explicitly promised Episode 3 never materialized, leaving the emotional tension at the conclusion of Episode 2 unresolved. If you are likely to find that upsetting, then it may be better to pass on this otherwise masterful experience.

If you enjoyed Half-Life, the original prequel, you would most likely enjoy this one as well.

Okay, I personally don't like the entirety of the games - I still finished all of them. I may have said Not Recommended, but I mean that I don't like it. Here is why.

1. Puzzles. I don't like puzzle games, even Portal. I think it drags them out too much. 
2. Length. It's a super long game and I'm not much of a fan of long games.
3. Complicated. So many weapons (I understand a lot of people like that, such as DOOM fans) and there are a lot of enemies. A lot of things to keep track of. 
4. I'm pretty bad at games. Call me a game journalist if you must, but I really suck at games and that rage I get from failing may be why I don't like it. 
5. Boring. A lot of waiting must be done. I don't mind waiting for the speeches though, I like that part. Most of the game is really slow, as well.
6. Community. A lot of (not most, just a lot of people) the community of the Half-Life games have kind of left me desensitized. 
7. Not fun for achievement hunters. I am one, and there are a lot of achievements, a lot super hard. It doesn't feel good when it's easy to miss. 

But there are some things I like. Here are a few.
1. Lore. Goddamn, the lore. The history, the events, the Combine, it's so amazing.
2. Characters. Alyx, Barney, Kleiner, Lamarr, Grigori, the like. I love the characters, and the dialog is one of the best parts. I don't mind waiting through speech.
3. Community (again). Some of the community is actually wholesome, and those willing to guide me through the game were a great help.
4. Buildup/plot. I won't spoil the plot. The plot is so fantastic, going from one place to another. Yes, sometimes dragged out, but still fun to go through. 
5. Speedrunning. Simply put, super fun to reverse-bhop, find routes, go fast. I don't speedrun games, but going quick is one of the ups to me.
Well made in every aspect

HALF LIFE 2, just like its predecessor aren't just games. They're experiences.  The games are the pinnacle of first person shooting, level design and character ego. You once again reprise the role of Gordon Freeman, a physicist who finds himself in the middle of an interstellar occupation on Earth by a race known as the Combine. They have brutally conquered Earth, subjugated mankind and are in the process of stripping the planet of its natural resources.  There is no hope until you show up, fresh out of limbo which you were slipped into by the elusive GMAN. He resurrects you and sends you to work against the Combine as if you- just little old you- can make the difference.   Ironically, you can!  Gordon will single handedly gun down waves of Combine footsoldiers, elite units and HG Wells styled Tripods with laser beams and warp cannons using conventional weapons and a will to keep moving forward!

I initially played this game on the original XBOX.  Hardware has changed considerably over the past 20 years.  Looking back, it's amazing Xbox was able to run this game, but it did so with massive framerate drops when the action heated up.  Now, in 2025, We have CPU, RAM, SSD drives and GPU more than 100 times as fast as that hardware. The game runs buttery smooth in the highest resolutions.

Half Life and Half Life 2 are both experiences.  A large portion of the game is spent gunning down heavily armed soldiers, but an equal amount of time is spent traversing the levels which feel connected to each other rather than independent of each other.  Unfortunately, a large amount of that time is also spent solving puzzles.  Physics puzzles.  You'll need to move boxes, pipes and other levers to access new locations. The first playthrough - it's OK.  The following playthroughs, it's simply annoying and slows down the pacing.   The gun battles with the Combine soldiers are roughly as good as they were with the Marine special ops in the original game. The difference is that their weapons are more powerful and they don't work as hard to flank you.  The reality is, they're at an extreme disadvantage because your HEV suit acts as battle armor and it's far more resilient to their weapons than they are. 

This game is very good, and I wish for a sequel, but the developers haven't given us Half Life 3 nor do they seem to have any finalized plans as to whether or not they'll do so. They did give us expansions to Half Life 2, but there is no solid conclusion to the war yet.   This game ends on a cliffhanger and you'll need Episode 1 and 2 - as well as Half Life: Alyx VR to enjoy the entire story.

Welcome to Half-Life 2, the game where the main character, Gordon Freeman, has a PhD in theoretical physics but chooses to solve most of his problems by bashing them with a crowbar.

In an era where heroes quip and shout, Half-Life 2 gives us Gordon Freeman, a man so stoically silent he makes the strong, silent type look chatty. The guy has seen it all—aliens, dystopian oppression, and enough explosions to make Michael Bay blush, and yet he utters not a single word. You’re a one-man army armed with science and silence, moving through a world that’s constantly on the edge of collapse.
Here’s the thing about Half-Life 2: you’re not really sure what’s going on half the time, and neither is Gordon. One minute you’re waking up from a multi-year nap, the next you’re being hunted by an alien regime called the Combine, all while a creepy suit-wearing dude (G-Man) keeps popping up, staring at you like he’s your weird uncle at a family gathering.

Half-Life 2 might look like a game about shooting aliens, but it’s really a lesson in physics. The Gravity Gun, the most overpowered science project since the Mentos-and-Coke experiment. With this bad boy, you can pick up nearly anything, barrels, boxes, saw blades, you name it, and launch it at your enemies with extreme prejudice. Why bother shooting when you can fling entire washing machines at foes?

City 17 is where Half-Life 2 is set, and if you’re into totalitarian regimes and grimy aesthetics, you’ll love it! The whole place feels like someone looked at Eastern European architecture and said, “Let’s make this more depressing.” The Combine patrol the city with zero chill, and their idea of a good time is chasing you down with stun batons, barking incomprehensible orders in a robotic voice. The city is both beautiful and terrifying, with crumbling buildings, abandoned railways, and the occasional glimpse of a giant alien tripod creature stomping around like it owns the place. 

If City 17 is depressing, Ravenholm is that extra dose of nightmare fuel you didn’t ask for, even the game itself warns you “We don’t go to Ravenholm.” It’s basically a haunted house with killer traps, headcrab zombies, and the overall aesthetic of a place you wouldn’t visit even if someone paid you. The vibe here? Spooky as hell, with just enough Silent Hill energy to make you question why you ever left the train in the first place.

The Half-Life 2 community is one of the most dedicated and passionate groups in gaming history. They’ve kept the game alive through mods, memes, and theories, all while maintaining a sense of humor about the fact that Valve has left them hanging for over a decade. HL2 isn’t just a game; it’s a cultural phenomenon, a collective nostalgia trip, and, perhaps most importantly, an ongoing inside joke that only gets funnier with time.

Half-Life 2 is a game that transcends its time. The blend of innovative gameplay, mysterious story, and a world filled with unforgettable moments creates an experience that stays with you long after you’ve beaten it.

[h1]Half-Life 2 – The Pinnacle of Gaming Excellence[/h1]
Half-Life 2 isn’t just a game; it’s a revolution. A masterpiece that redefined the gaming industry with its unparalleled storytelling, groundbreaking physics engine, and unforgettable atmosphere. Even in 2025, it remains one of the most immersive and technically impressive experiences ever crafted.

[h2]A Legacy That Shook the Industry:[/h2]
When Half-Life 2 was released in 2004, it sent shockwaves through the gaming world. Valve introduced Havok Physics, allowing realistic object interaction that was unheard of at the time. From using the Gravity Gun to launch barrels at enemies to solving physics-based puzzles, the game was way ahead of its time. Even today, many modern FPS games fail to match its level of interaction.

[h2]A Timeless Story in a Dystopian World:[/h2]
Half-Life 2 picks up years after the Black Mesa Incident from the first game. The world has fallen under the control of the Combine, an oppressive alien force that governs Earth with an iron fist. As Gordon Freeman, the silent yet iconic protagonist, players join the resistance, fighting for the survival of humanity.

The story unfolds in a cinematic yet seamless manner, without cutscenes breaking the immersion. Each chapter introduces new gameplay elements, locations, and enemies, making every moment feel fresh. From the eerie streets of City 17 to the desolate landscapes of Highway 17, every area is filled with environmental storytelling that deepens the world’s lore.

[h2]Characters That Feel Alive:[/h2]
Valve’s facial animation technology was revolutionary for its time, making characters incredibly expressive. Iconic figures like:

[b]Alyx Vance[/b] – A brilliantly written companion with realistic AI and deep emotional weight.

[b]Dr. Kleiner & Dr. Eli Vance[/b] – Scientists who guide Gordon and bring humor and warmth.

[b]Barney Calhoun[/b] – A resistance fighter and an old friend from Black Mesa.

[b]G-Man[/b] – The enigmatic figure who pulls the strings behind the scenes, shrouded in mystery.

Each character has memorable dialogues and interactions, making the world feel alive.

[h2]A Masterpiece in Game Design:[/h2]
Every level in Half-Life 2 is a work of art. The game never holds your hand, yet its level design naturally guides you toward objectives. From navigating zombie-infested Ravenholm to leading the resistance in City 17, every chapter is unique and unforgettable.

The atmosphere is second to none. The blend of gritty realism and sci-fi dystopia creates a setting that is both immersive and hauntingly believable.

[h2]RTX Update – A New Era for Half-Life 2:[/h2]
A fully ray-traced version of Half-Life 2 is on the horizon, bringing:
✅ [b]Advanced lighting & reflections[/b]
✅ [b]Enhanced textures & models[/b]
✅ [b]Even more realistic physics interactions[/b]

With this update, Half-Life 2 will once again set the standard for gaming visuals. It’s incredible to think that a game from 2004 is about to look better than most modern titles!

[h2]Final Verdict:[/h2]
Half-Life 2 is not just a game; it’s an artistic and technical milestone that continues to inspire generations of developers. If you’ve never played it, you’re missing out on one of the greatest gaming experiences of all time. With the RTX update coming soon, now is the perfect time to (re)experience this legendary masterpiece.

[h2][b]⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (10/10) - Masterpiece 👑🎮🔥
A timeless classic that remains unbeaten.[/b][/h2]

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Review:

Half-Life 2 is one of those rare games that lives up to all the hype and even exceeds expectations. It’s been over a decade since its release, but it still holds up as one of the best first-person shooters ever made.

The game picks up where the first one left off, with Gordon Freeman now in a dystopian world controlled by an alien race known as the Combine. The story is told in such a seamless, immersive way—there are no cutscenes, just you moving through the world and piecing things together as you go. It’s one of the best examples of world-building in a game.

The physics engine is a game-changer. The way you can manipulate objects in the environment with the iconic gravity gun adds so much fun to the combat and puzzle-solving. It's one of those simple ideas that feels revolutionary. Combine that with some of the most memorable set pieces, and it’s hard not to get sucked into the world of City 17.

The AI is still impressive even by today’s standards, with enemies reacting to your movements and using the environment to their advantage. The combat is diverse, and there’s a nice mix of shootouts, vehicle segments, and platforming. Plus, the pacing is spot on—there’s never a dull moment.

Visually, Half-Life 2 was a stunner back in 2004, and while the graphics might look dated now, the art design, lighting, and atmosphere still give it a timeless feel. The environments, from the ruined cities to the eerie coastlines, are still some of the best-designed in any game.

Half-Life 2 isn’t just a great shooter; it’s an experience. The narrative, the gameplay, and the world it builds come together in a way few games can match. If you haven't played it yet, you’re missing out on a true gaming classic.

Pros:

Incredible world-building and storytelling
Revolutionary physics with the gravity gun
Diverse and satisfying combat
Great AI and smart enemy behavior
Stunning atmosphere and level design
Cons:

Some sections can feel a bit slow or repetitive
Graphics are a bit dated by modern standards, but the atmosphere still shines

This is one of those games that set the bar for first-person shooters, and it’s still an absolute must-play. If you haven’t played it yet, what are you waiting for?

I love this game with all my heart. The fact that it still looks more visually appealing than most modern games despite it being over 20 years old is a testament to the innovations it made. And despite it's age, it's still so fun to replay.

"A Classic That Still Holds Up, but Shows Its Age"

Game Name: Half-Life 2
Rating: 🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟☆☆☆☆ (6/10)

My Experience: 🔫
Half-Life 2 is a legendary game that helped define the first-person shooter genre, and playing it years later gave me a sense of nostalgia, but also made me realize just how much the gaming landscape has evolved since its release. The story is still captivating, and the setting remains immersive, but some of the game mechanics feel outdated. While it has a strong narrative and a memorable protagonist in Gordon Freeman, the experience feels slower and less fluid compared to modern shooters.

Gameplay: ⚙️
The gameplay, which once felt revolutionary, is now showing its age. The physics engine was ahead of its time, and it still stands out in some puzzles and combat sequences. However, the gunplay feels a bit clunky compared to more modern FPS titles, and the AI, while decent for its time, can feel a bit predictable now. The pacing also fluctuates, with some sections feeling unnecessarily drawn out, and the lack of significant upgrades to gameplay mechanics can make the experience feel stale at times. While it still offers fun moments, it’s hard to ignore its dated feel.

Conclusion: 🕹️
Half-Life 2 is undeniably a classic and a must-play for fans of the genre, but it’s hard to overlook how much it’s aged. The story, atmosphere, and puzzles still hold up, but the outdated mechanics and slower pacing can make it a tough sell for newcomers who are used to more polished, fast-paced shooters. It’s a game that paved the way for many of today’s best FPS titles, but it might not have the same impact now as it did when it first released.

Half-Life 2 isn’t just a game—it’s a masterpiece. Even after all these years, it still holds up as one of the greatest FPS experiences ever made. The story, the atmosphere, the gameplay—everything just works. It’s the kind of game that makes you wonder, "Why can’t more modern shooters be this good?"

This game came out 2 weeks before my 2nd birthday, here I am 21 years later writing about how much of a masterpiece it STILL is.

From the moment you step into City 17, you know you’re in for something special. The world feels alive (in a dystopian, "Big Brother is watching" kind of way), the characters are memorable, and the pacing is chef’s kiss. One minute, you’re exploring a desolate highway, the next, you’re fighting through zombie-infested tunnels with a gravity gun and a saw blade. And speaking of the gravity gun—this thing changed gaming. It made physics fun, something most shooters still fail to do today.

Of course, this is Valve we’re talking about, so naturally, there’s one big problem: Where is Half-Life 3? We’ve been waiting for nearly two decades, and all we got was Half-Life: Alyx (which is amazing, but not what we asked for). It’s like Valve made one of the best games of all time and then just said, “Yeah, we’re done now.”

But despite the heartbreak of never getting a true sequel, Half-Life 2 remains a must-play. It’s the reason we have so many incredible FPS mechanics today, and even in 2025, it’s still better than most shooters on the market.

TL;DR:
An all-time classic that still holds up. Amazing story, perfect pacing, and the gravity gun is legendary. The only downside? Valve refuses to make Half-Life 3.

[h3][noparse][Will add in addition details to the review later on. I plan on writing something comprehensive. Review is subject to change, rephrases and rewrites.][/noparse][/h3]
I received this through the Orange Box bundle.

[h1]Review:[/h1]
[list]
[*] > Gameplay is excellent.
[*] > Story is interesting.
[*] > Weapon choices are fun.
[/list]
[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]
The Source Engine has to be some of the best, and one of my favorites, in this industry, though, my knowledge about its inner workings are limited. My coding literacy is lacking.

But I find how it functions in-game to be fun, the way it simulates physics is the most realistic, and I feel, hasn't been replicated by any other game besides LittleBigPlanet. The mentioned game is a PlayStation title created by [b]Media Molecule.[/b]

The gravity gun showcases how items can interact with the world and against hostile NPCs such as headcrabs. Using blunt force in this fashion isn't something you come across much in other games.

[h2]Story:[/h2]
I haven't finished the story just yet, but I'm nearly towards the end.

So far, it's an interesting story but I'm not a writer so I couldn't give any technical knowledge about its structure or composition. It has Star Trek levels of scientific insight, you can easily tell that collage graduates with multiple PhDs and doctorates wrote all of these sci-fi elements.

[h2]Weapon variety:[/h2]
I'm not a weapons expert, but I still enjoy the weapon choices. As I've checked from YouTube videos discussing how Half-Life 1 is designed to make you think before you act, I'm sure Half-Life 2 works the same way. These are designed as utilities as well as defensive tools, it's not exclusively about killing hostiles.

The multiple options are there to give you different ways to experiment and solve a puzzle.

There's no doubt that Half Life 2 is one of the most iconic games of all time. It essentially kickstarted Valve's era of making memorable games in the Source engine (which is still capable of making great environments to this day), and this game does have good set pieces and level design.

When I first reviewed this game after beating it, I gave it a perfect 10/10 on the count of me never having played Half Life 1 before, and the fact that I had learned of all its in-jokes from playing so much Garry's Mod. 212 hours later, multiple deep dives into this game's cut content, and several playthroughs of Half Life 1 later, Half Life 2 just does not stand on its own for me.

So why am I re-reviewing this now, you ask? To answer that, I'd like to ask you something; What did Half Life 2 even innovate? Why did this game NEED to come out as it shipped in 2004?

You might say, "Because of the physics!" Alright, cool, but Psy-Ops, Postal II, Max Payne 2, and Hitman had physics engines long before this game did. "Oh, but they weren't as well used." All this game uses its physics engine for is overusing the gravity gun, counter-weight puzzles here and there, and an overrated, contrived E3 Demo. Sure, it's fun to use the gravity gun to chuck physics objects at enemies and send them flying with all of the rather conveniently-placed barrels and pallets strewn everywhere, but that wears off once you realize that using the shotgun and pulse rifle is always going to be the dominant strategy. 

The weapons are actually where I have the most amount of grievances with Half Life 2. In Half Life 1, you began with your standard pistols, SMGs, a shotgun, and grenades. All of them were viable, even into the later chapters, but where it really shone were the experimental weapons, like the Tau Cannon and the Alien Grunt's Hive Hand. The difference between these weapons and the Gravity Gun in Half Life 2 is that the developers didn't rub in your face how cool it was, they just introduced them when the time was right and when it made sense to give you these new weapons. The expansion packs did even better with this, introducing the Barnacle, Shock Roach, and Displacer Cannon in Opposing Force that allowed you to traverse the levels in new ways and were legitimately good alternatives to your standard hitscan guns.

Given all of this, how does Half Life 2 handle its weapon roster? A bug ball that doesn't even need to be used for the chapter its in, and a physics gimmick that overstays its welcome since it's given to you not even halfway through. Instead of coming up with cool alien weapons for the enemy to use, they have them shoot pellet guns at you for the entire runtime. There is no point to this, you've already committed to the alien invasion plot, you wouldn't spoil anything by having more than ONE futuristic gun for the player to use. That isn't to say Half Life 2 has nothing satisfying to its gunplay, it certainly does when it comes to providing visual feedback, but at some point it becomes repetitive to shoot the same exact grunt over and over. 

Now let's get to the story, which is one thing the game always gets praised for. Ah yes, because I remember the [i]best[/i] part of Half Life being the first chapter where nothing happens for 10 minutes before the game lets you get to the good stuff. In Half Life 2, Valve decided to make the most boring part of Half Life into two chapters of dialogue that Gordon can't be a part of, and thus can't connect us with in any meaningful way.

"Oh, ha ha ha, isn't Barney so silly, the way he always said he'd buy you a beer and how Gordon totally knows who he is despite every security guard in Black Mesa being the same character model?" 

It's insulting to your intelligence, and it's tedious to listen to each time you play through the game. Half Life 1 kept character dialogue out because Valve knew the limitations of Gordon not being able to speak, and it was about escaping a stressful disaster scenario where there isn't time for lengthy dialogue. Half Life 2, on the other hand, has the characters put on a smug face every time they reference a random detail about the first game or make a quip that makes you either cringe or smile along with them the first time and only the first time. 

The last thing that sucks a lot of the joy out of Half Life 2 for me is the setting. This game went through a lot of changes to its art style and vision during its 6 years of development, and I'd blame the leak for a lot of this. The Combine are just not that interesting, nor are they anywhere near as oppressive as everyone says they are. This is supposed to be an apocalyptic story of alien oppressors controlling the Earth as its natural life is dying off, and yet: 

-The Coast is almost perfectly intact, with rather decent water levels given the 20 year gap between these two games
-City 17 is in really good shape despite the 7-hour-war that took place offscreen destroying cities and supposedly introducing Xen fauna into the Earth's ecosystem
-Every character distracts from it by making jokes and doing nothing but praising Gordon as a messiah despite him being a large part of the reason for why the world is as fucked as it is.

Something tells me that this is because of the playtesters Valve hired. They had all these amazing concepts for returning enemies from the first game like Bullsquids, Houndeyes, and Gargantuas as well as entirely new enemies like the Hydra and Combine Guards and Stalkers, but all it took was a playtester saying "Hydra isn't fun because I don't feel like God when I fight it" for any ideas to get dropped. Because Valve couldn't bear the idea of you not feeling like the reincarnation of Jesus, any sense of futility or hopelessness against the state of this world can't last for more than 20 minutes, and any plot threads from Half Life 1 were dropped because too many people cried over the Xen chapters. Because of this, HL2's enemy roster ended up being zombies, antlions that die in one hit from a shotgun, and humanoids with zero personality. It really has not aged well.

So, what's my new verdict on Half Life 2? It is good if you're a fan of the franchise, but it is not the greatest game ever made by any stretch, nor was it really all that influential. It certainly has its moments, but I'm glad people can now realize that it is not a proper sequel to Half Life and the marketing made it look much better than it was. I highly recommend you to play the Episodes, though, and chances are I'll make a review of those that'll be far more positive, because I think even Valve was disappointed with the direction this game had to go at the last minute and wanted to give it a make-over.

This is my last review of 2024.

Half-Life 2 manages to ditch what Half-Life did wrong, and implemented new mechanics that are carried over through an entire act or more, to make your gameplay interesting. It removes most of the cheap deaths you could have, and have you taking part into action more often.

This game is packed with Episode 1 and 2 (whose should actually be played after you play Half-Life 2 if you want to follow the story, because the chronology of this game is odd).
It also has support to mods, if you want to alter your gameplay experience.
The only disappointment is that this game has no multiplayer support, which is a pity, because this game would be nice to play the campaign with friends.

Like the first game, this game offers a kind of cinematic experience, where as Gordon Freeman, you pass through his journey throughout the plot of the game, while also meeting new characters, be they friends or foes.

The first game, which is Half-Life 2, and I'll call episode 0, is the lone journey of Gordon until he reaches the citadel. He will meet many friends along the way, and also foes. Some acts introduce new mechanics you can use and abuse through the acts they're useable, which makes the gameplay a lot more fun. I actually had lots of fun with the acts where I used the pheromone pod to command an army of antlions.

The second game, Half-Life 2 Episode 1, has Alyx accompanying you, as you two try to escape from the Citadel. The acts are actually really short, and you'll probably be blazing through it if you play for a few hours. If you like Alyx, this act is for you.
Sadly, it doesn't introduce much new stuff you can play with.

The third game, Half-Life 2 Episode 2, also has Alyx accompanying with you for most of the playthrough, but at certain moments you'll either be alone, or accompanied by a Vortigaunt (plot reasons). The acts are actually longer, and also has a enjoyable gameplay experience too. Just in my opinion, the final boss fight of the act is really straining, even if you're playing on Easy mode.

After passing through this whole journey, while also having mods to alter my experience and make things funny, I had a good time with this game, and the story made me interested. Sadly, the game ends with a cliff hanger at the end of Episode 2, which explains why lots of people keep saying they want Half-Life 3.
I don't think Half-Life 3 would be necessary, but an Episode 3 to finish what 2 ended would do.

Anyways, due to the mod support, this game will have access also to user created content, so players can make new campaigns and stuff for the game. I even was playing an adventure one that was in spanish (but couldn't proceed because a paper I had to read had a glow obstructing my view).

Anyways, this game is fun, and I had a greater time here than on Half-Life. But still, is still a pity that there's no multiplayer support.
I'm aware Synergy exists, but that mod seems really buggy. But anyways, feel free to get this game and play, because you'll like it.

And if you want to increment you experience, download a few wacky mods :).
Just enjoy the ride, heh.

An absolute classic that deserves to be played by everyone. Of course, some parts of it didn't age too well, but it was overall a fun experience and even featured a couple of nice physics-based puzzles. They had some great ideas back in the day ^^

[h2]Achievements[/h2]
[b]Required time:[/b] 17-25 hours
[b]Difficulty (in my opinion):[/b] 4 out of 10
[b]DLCs required for 100%?:[/b] No

The achievement list of the base game is great. You need to play through the game on any difficulty you want and get all the collectible Lambda caches. There are also some nice combat-related achievements. Nothing too hard and quite fun. 

With the 20th Anniversary Update, Episodes 1 and 2 were added to Half-Life 2. So, if you’re going for 100% completion, you’ll need to grab all the Episode 1 and 2 achievements too. If you already unlocked them in the standalone games, you can import your save, and the achievements will autopop. If not (like me), you’ll have to get them again in Half-Life 2.

The achievements aren’t too hard, but some are definitely annoying. In Episode 1, you’re only allowed to fire a single bullet the entire time - challenging, but doable. Episode 2 has you carrying a garden gnome through the whole episode. It starts out fun but gets frustrating fast, especially when you’re trying to drive it around in the car.

And let’s not forget the “kill 333 grubs” achievement in Episode 2. Honestly, it’s near impossible without a guide, so I’d highly recommend checking out Cynic 0055’s achievement guides - they’re super helpful. The rest of the achievements aren’t too bad and shouldn’t give you much trouble.

All that remains is one final question: where HL3? o_O

After completing the main game of Half-Life 2, I can’t help but feel that it’s overrated. While it's often regarded as one of the greatest games of all time, I found it to be a mixed bag, especially compared to its predecessor, Half-Life 1.

One of my main gripes with the game is how frequently it left me feeling bored and even dizzy. The pacing seemed inconsistent, with moments that dragged on far longer than necessary. Additionally, the level design was often frustrating, as I found myself losing my way multiple times, which disrupted the flow of the story and made progression feel more tedious than engaging.

That being said, I can appreciate why Half-Life 2 was groundbreaking in its time. Released in 2004, it boasted a good attention to detail, and voice acting. If I had played it closer to its original release, I might have rated it more favorably for these innovations.

For now, I’m planning to continue with Episode One, Episode Two, and Lost Coast to see if these expansions can change my perspective. Maybe they’ll highlight what so many fans find special about this series and make the overall experience more enjoyable for me.

Update #1:
I just finished Ep1, i dont know why but i liked it way more than the main one, i will definitely continue with Ep2, the ending got me intrigue to see the end of the story

Update #2:
I finished Episode 2 two weeks ago, and much like Episode 1, I found it thoroughly enjoyable. That said, I still consider Episode 1 the strongest entry in the series so far. but I can’t help feeling frustrated by the ending of Episode 2. How could they leave the story on such a cliffhanger and then leave fans waiting for 17 years (and counting) without any closure? It’s easy to see why the open-ended story has left fans feeling both deeply attached and incredibly frustrated over the years

I've played this game many times before this account on consoles and played it many times since this account on PC. This is one of the greatest shooters, and games of all time. There is no objective icon or "follow character." This game comes from an era where it's up to you to figure things out; It does not spoon feed you directions or hints. There are also no cut-scenes in the game. The story is all told through in-game models and animation. The graphics hold up well for being as old as it is and the level of polish to the physics, combat, AI and puzzles make this a beacon of inspiration for many in the gaming industry and more fun than many of the games releasing today. I have replayed this game many times and it is one of my all time favorites. This game was the first to do so many things that virtually all shooters and many games still do to this day.

Where's my beer, Barney?

Bloody incredible game. The atmosphere, the worldbuilding, the story, the physics puzzles--everything about this is like a Shakespearean play written in code and 3d animations. Minus a few old bugs--characters not being where they were supposed to (ahem, Barney)--and some confusion on where I was supposed to go on maps, this is indeed the hype machine that everyone thinks it is.

Just know that there will never be a completion to this series. A symptom of the modern age's shying away from finishing off possible perfection, perhaps.

Game is good but has some issues of 'the player can do this' rather than 'the player will do this' in testing. Like a problem of how averages leave out outliers, and how your testing sample differs from the gaming population average, so there is a larger pool of outliers than expected. 

Eventually relying on averages of data is just noise and misleading, because its averages of averages of samples. Eventually there is just more outlier than in-grouper. And thats when you fail, thats when philosophy fails, thats when institutions fail, thats when science fails. Its like an echo chamber. If you keep appealing to average, eventually you are appealing to just people who are too afraid to stand out in any way shape or form. 

So designing a smooth experience tho, to impress upon journalists or something, that might not really require a multilayered approach. But for longevity more than just legend, you would want to have a multi-layer approach. Like, tall people exist too, need to make some tall clothes not just average american wide.

This isn't really anything new I'm saying and I don't wanna give a false impression of what kind of person I am. Like, Pyro and Sniper are examples of classes with lower skill floor. So I'm sure some have design philosophy already. Idk the costs of it. But if we look at how much players got the crowbar, vs, how many made it past that flood the room level, more than 20% of players were lost in that timeframe. I felt it, but I kept going. So just saying, there was some kind of assumption forming about how a person tries to problem solve, that effects the game pacing. And if the gamer doesn't know what Gman or the developers are expecting you to do, then they're just guessing n checking. And then if their guess could work part way but is artificially designed to not work, it just feels disincentivizing to think of creative solutions. 

For example, oil floats on water, nice. Why does me jumping on a barrel in water make it explode? Its better, to let me go with my method through the pipe, then realize 'oh I need to fill this chamber with water to ascend.' Than to like, explode, and then be left wondering. When I was in the other room, I saw the health crate and my mind completely didnt notice the valve it was under. Perhaps this is a monkey trap of sorts. Adhd, or just being near-sighted so am not used to seeing wide, or perhaps my color saturation was a bit low so didn't notice the valve which was red. And, other ladders, sometimes I had that problem of visibility with to. But because of the sharpness of the edge of the steps of the ladder, them blending into their environment wasn't a big deal, but I think with different pc or settings it might have been too blended in. And this could explain the 20% dropoff. 

So a real solution might be, to make jank rigs with jank settings and see how smoothly it plays. Like, a problem of over-standardization of testing perhaps. Maybe you could make a project computer that can emulate a wide variety of types of computers so you can rapidly test various experiences, without requiring multiple pcs or reassembly. But perhaps this problem is solved with the Steam OS stuff in a way.

I write this review for the people that like me, have only just discovered the Half Life games. Well! What can I say about this game. It is now over 20 years old, yet feels as fresh as a lot of the present day games. I have only recently discovered the Half Life Saga, and can truly say I'm hooked. The game is long and engrossing, and the environments are amazing! You would never believe the age of it. There is a great deal of different weapons and all bar one, have a limited ammo clip. You're constantly looking around for health power ups and ammo that you tend to ignore the enemy raining down on you until it's too late. Then there's the VR Mod which brings in a whole new experience to the game. I just think it's an amazing game that I have played through several times already, and will probably play again a lot more in the future.

Half-Life 2 is a First-Person shooter developed by Valve, and is considered one of the greatest games of all time... with good reason. Half-Life 2 has some of the coolest elements I have ever seen in a game.
Pros:
-Great Narrative is continued through a total FP perspective like Half-Life
-Well designed characters 
-Fun weapons, even cooler than Half-Life
-REALLY GOOD GRAPHICS (When I first played this game I thought it was a recently made game, but NOPE this game was made in 2004... 2004!!!)
-Variety of scenarios (You will be doing different things throughout the game and not just killing anything that moves)

Cons:
-At times some of the levels can be long and barren especially in the Highway 17 section
-Physics engine can be a pain sometimes especially in the Water Hazard  chapter where your air boat can be flipped over and you can't easily put it back up
-No Half-Life 3

Overall, (9.7/10) Half-Life 2 is a MUST HAVE for any steam user, despite minimal flaws this game is almost perfect. Now go get The Orange Box or GabeN will find you.

Half Life 2
Valve

I get it now.

Half Life 2 is a shooter campaign of extreme quality and spectacle, showing that games are able to have meaningful puzzles and thoughtful combat encounters, while still being wonderfully cinematic. I also understand why there still isn’t - a week past HL2s 20th anniversary - a Half Life 3. Valve has proven themselves to be at the forefront of game technology and design, and if they couldn’t find something to push the medium forward in meaningful ways - Half Life 2’s ridiculously good physics engine, gravity gun, graphical fidelity, character models, ect - then why bother? 

It is no surprise that the only Half Life entry we have gotten since is Half Life Alyx. If you cannot find a way to meaningfully innovate in a given medium - the first person shooter - then go to another medium, and show the world how to do it. In the year of our lord 2024, Half Life Alyx seems to be the only true AAA VR title, and none other seem to even come close.

I cannot imagine what it was like to experience this in 2004. If today it still managed to show a refreshing amount of originality and ingenuity, then it must have been unimaginably groundbreaking when it released.

I played Half-Life 2 again after a long time. And I'm going to be real, the game is not that great. I got here after playing Half-Life and the expansions, and they were nice. Half Life was good and Opposing Force was even better, in my opinion. Half-Life 2 is something else entirely though, and depending on who you are, that might be a good or a bad thing. 

Coming from the previous game, I hated the airboat section. After playing Half-Life 1, it feels like it was disrespectful to the player's resource management. But, it also teaches the player how the game works, because at the end of the segment, the game makes sure to basically refill your entire health and energy, and give you more ammo than you entered the section with. Half-Life 2 almost always makes sure you have what you need. It's a kind game, and that's nice.  While I'm talking about airboats though, I gotta say something. Did you know that airboats are real? Like they're not something made up for Half-Life 2! My mind was blown when I found out. 

The game has a bit of tech demo energy to it. It feels like a bunch of smaller parts of different games stitched together. Especially the two different vehicle sections split up by a little area with like... horror elements. It's kind of funny.

There's a part of the game where you get people who follow you around, and command them, but they never stay when you tell them to, it feels almost like they want to get killed. ): The AI foes aren't shy about tossing grenades, and it feels like they're somewhat tactical about it, there's this stairway where they get to blow up 4 squad members with a grenade at a time. It's somewhat humorous. 

This game is fine, it's totally not the best, but it has a little bit of charm to it. I had fun in parts, and other parts made me groan. Overall Half-Life 2 is an okay game. However, now that Episode 1 and 2 are part of the game, I can't really recommend this game to people. Did you ever buy an Early Access game and you are looking forward to the next update, and then the developers decide not to add anything to the game for the next decade? That's this game, this is the Early Access game where the developers never finish the game, that's what Half-Life 2 and the Episodes are.

Half life 2 is a cult classic and one of the most influential games in the history of the medium. When it came out in 2004, it revolutionized both physics in games, and the presentation of all FPS games coming after it. Although I prefer the original Half Life more than this one, I still think it's an excellent game and I very much enjoy it. The only complaint I possibly have is that it isn't paced as well as Half Life. Otherwise, it builds upon all the mechanics of its source, and innovates and expands the experience. Since a couple months ago, they did an update on the game, which gave general QoL improvements and merged the two episodes into the main game. The episodes are great too, and I only hate that episode two ended on a cliffhanger 18 years ago and there are still no plans to continue the story. Overall, I very much recommend everyone to try and play Half Life and Half Life 2 at least once. Both casual gamers and fans of fps. It seriously holds its place in game history.

Así como el primer juego considero que este también es juego de culto y obligatorio luego de pasarse el primero. En este caso no se notan tanto los años como en el 1 ya que las actualizaciones que le fueron metiendo con el tiempo hacen que se vea bastante bien considerando el tiempo que tiene, y la jugabilidad no es tan "tanque" como sí pasaba con el 1. También las mejoras que tiene este juego en la parte gráfica permiten que la historia se disfrute mucho más y hasta se entienda mejor. 

Todo el tiempo de juego que tengo constituye tanto la historia principal como los dos episodios que continúan la historia y la verdad bastante bien. Recomendé en el 1 jugar directamente Black Mesa así que este, al no tener un remaster, hay que comprarlo sí o sí pero considero que además de que es obligatorio vale bien lo que cueste (que no sé si es mucho la verdad). En caso de que no moleste jugar el 1 original recomendaría comprar el pack que tiene Steam con todos los juegos de Valve para así poder jugar también los DLC's que sacaron. En ese sentido me gustó que ya venga todo incluido en este juego y no haya que comprar los dos episodios adicionales ya que luego de terminar la historia principal es necesario seguir con esos (y hubiera sido un bajón tener que comprarlos aparte)

Me pareció un juego bastante bueno, ya había leído que algunos lo consideran de los mejores de la historia y tampoco es que les falte razón. Si bien tiene sus puntos a mejorar en cosas que no me gustaron como el hecho de que se puedan desviar los proyectiles del lanzacohetes (bastante molesto) o la "mecánica" que agregaron de poder prender fuego los barriles y poder matar a los bichos que se cuelgan del techo de una (aunque teniéndolo que calcular bien, yo simplemente les disparaba para hacerlo más rápido), me gustó más que el 1 porque siento que se explotó mucho más el mundo abierto (el capítulo del coche donde hay que recorrer ciudades y lootearlas, mi favorito) y con las mejoras gráficas lo disfruté más

This one of the best first person shooter games I've ever played, plain and simple.

Half Life 2 begins 20 years after the original Half Life. As Gordon Freeman awakens from stasis he finds himself on a train heading to City 17 which is overrun by the combine. You find yourself as the leader of the resistance and you must take down the Combine.

Half Life 2 is at this point one of the best received games and I'm sure pretty much everyone has played it. If not well what the hell are you doing reading this review ? You need to go buy this game straight away and play it right now.

The game is a simple first person shooter, but it does plenty things different than the regular first person shooters. You have a health bar and you have to do platforming to solve some of the puzzles. Not to mention the source engine physics are absolutely insane.

For a game that came out back in 2004 it still looks amazing. Now while it does have so low res textures it's still looks breath taking, like in the final chapters.

The game for the most part is pretty easy. I played through the game without a problem, even though some segments were tough due to the fast movement you have to pull off to avoid gunfire. Not to mention the Strider battles are incredibly intense and quite difficult.

The game took me 10 hours to finish. I felt this was the perfect amount of time for the price I paid for it and this was worth every single penny.

Apart from the single playthrough there's not much replay value. The only reason to replay it twice is to look for the G-Man Easter eggs.

In the end Half Life 2 is a fantastic game. It's a must own for everyone who is a gamer. This game is a piece of history and without a doubt one of the best games I have ever played in my entire life.

I experienced zero problems while playing the game. I ran the game on ultra settings 60 FPS the entire time of playing. This game runs really well and should run on pretty much all systems.

Final Rating:
9.5/10 - A Must own and must play

HL2 has got to be one of the most boring over-hyped games I have ever played. And before you say it, yes, I understand that the game came out in 2004. And I can enjoy games that came out then, and even before then. All things considered, I was actually pretty impressed with the graphics, sound quality, and physics. So I didn't dislike the game because of that. No, I disliked the game simply for having bad gameplay. Ah yes, gameplay, the one thing people always forget to mention when praising this game. Oh the physics, oh the story, oh the blah blah blah. Now, correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't the whole point of playing a game to idk PLAY a game?! Maybe I have a different sense of fun than most people, but going from point a to b to y to z because the teleporter broke just isn't my cup of tea. And during that track of a to b etc., you get encountered with an glorious obstacle that you'll have to repeat ad nauseam for the next hour. Because apparently filling levels with obstacle maneuvering is more fun than filling it with action, which is a lot to ask for, especially considering that this is an FPS! But all of that pales in comparison to the vehicle sections, which is by far the jankiest experience I have EVER had operating a vehicle in any video game. The speed bike from Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy handled better than the vehicles in this game. 

Honestly I tried with this game, and it's not like I didn't want to like it. I liked HL1, and can totally understand why people like it. But not this game, NOT this game.

With that all being said, should you play HL2? Yes, but only because on sale this game is around $1 and change. Thus it's worth it to play it past the refund period in order to experience the hype and cultivate your own opinion.

The game "Half-Life 2" holds a special place in the hearts of many gamers. For a game that is over 20 years old, it still stands up to the quality of games today. The unique level design involving a physics engine is very entertaining and keeps you immersed within the game. I recommend this game for people looking for a fps with lots of story. In regards to the previous game in the series, Half-Life, I do recommend playing it first. However, if you are unable to obtain it, the first game is not necessary. There are a few nods to the original but mostly a completely different environment than the original.

Может казаться, что надо быть поехавшим чтобы игру, рассчитанную на 12-13 часов прохождения, играть вот уже 10 год подряд оставляя за собой море времени, тысячи часов прохождения первой части, различных дополнений официальных и не только, 2-ой части, эпизодов и т.д. - но это единственная игра, которая уводит тебя под саунды Келли Бэйли в мир Half-Life, в мир где "он — словно озарение, после него понимаешь, какой гадостью тебя кормили последние годы". Мир, который как бриллиант, который навсегда. Который при каждом новом запуске оного открывается по разному. [h1] Nothing to say here. Half Life 2 still deserves the attention of every person who's enjoying playing games out there (and not only theirs). [/h1] 

Its gameplay and storyline are so solid, and the first person experience is just exemplary!! It handles all the mechanics so majestically and combines "REAL LIFE physics" puzzles (meaning that you can think and act like you would in real life) with an amazing artificial intelligence attached to everything. The world you've being introduced is perfectly composed, with every little detail pretty well fitted in. But the strong point here is the storytelling. From the eyes of Dr. Freeman, the player gets the chance to REALLY live the story and do things that he could never imagine doing in a videogame. Half Life 2, with no doubt, is the best FPS and videogame in general I've ever played, and not just because all these things I mentioned, but because the developers put their very souls into this. THIS IS ART. 

This game brought the "revolution" at the gaming industry and it's a masterpiece that can guide many developers to the "right way". AMAZING fps, AMAZING characters, AMAZING world, AMAZING prequel, AMAZING sequel episodes, A MUST PLAY!
Half-Life 2 is a landmark title in all of gaming, and now it's been updated so all Half-Life 2 content is available from just one executable. Go play it if you haven't already!

20 years later, Half-Life 2 still ages very well, making fans of the game come back to it and pull in newcomers to be amazed of what it achieved in 2004. The new update finally combines the base game and the episodes, making it seamless to play, as well as touching up on its visuals and fixing some bugs. Workshop support is added, which means modding the game will be easier this time around with mods offering visual tweaks and some minor bug fixing, as well as model swapping some NPCs to make the game such as mess to play. 

There are things that did not age well such as the janky physics system (which can be funny to watch tbh). pacing in some chapters that can drag replayability, bland gunplay that makes combat unsatisfying, as well as the squad AI being unreliable in some areas. But even with these faults, Half-Life 2 offers seamless integration of narrative and gameplay where it feels seamless to play instead of just watching a cutscene and going into gameplay. I still think that Valve is the only developer that does this perfectly, where it is replicated in Portal and Left 4 Dead. 

Half-Life 2 still stood the test of time that built the foundation of AAA for better or for worse. Either way, I highly recommend this game not only for historic purposes and probably lamenting that Valve didn't make Episode 3, but also experience this great game. 

(sidenote: if you plan to subscribe to workshop items, do not subscribe to more than 40 mods, as this can break subtitles)

While Alyx may be this series' peak, Half-Life 2 is still my most cherished piece of media ever created.

This could absolutely be a case of me wearing my rose-tinted goggles too much because of Valve games being almost my entire childhood, but there's a reason this game continues to receive praise to this very day.

There are annoyances & faults like the over-reliance on physics puzzles to show off the (at the time) impressive tech, overly drawn out dialogue segments that you cannot skip, which gets rather boring after you've played through the game more than twice like I have, and rather bland gun play even for the time it was released (Look up MMod to fix that particular problem).

In retrospect, it *has* aged and there are some rough spots, but it still holds up extremely well 20+ years later. A pillar stone of video game history and a must play for anybody that has any remote interest in this overpriced hobby. Frequently on sale for less than a moderate size bag of chips and it runs on practically every computer built in the last 16-odd years, so you really have no excuse.

This is one of those giant cultural-force-type games where so many others have written much better stuff than I could about how amazing & groundbreaking this game is, so I will just say:

If you don't own it, buy it and play as soon as possible. It won't disappoint you.

This game has also received a fantastic update from Valve recently on top of giving access to episodes 1 and 2 for free instead of having to pay for them individually. Very cool move on their part, and gets noggins joggin about a potential HL3... 

This remains one of maybe 3 stories in a video game that demanded my attention. Dialogue gets a bit cheeseball in places, but the depth of emotion in the characters' faces and mannerisms seems impossible to pull off in 2004, and still holds up even now. The way the story is told naturalistically by the characters is unparalleled, and avoids the immersion-breaking pitfalls of typical cutscenes.

That's all I can think to say that isn't a complete retread of something someone else has said better.

Rating: Just fkn buy it already/10

Just... Wow... There has been many things already said about this masterpiece of a game, so I will keep it short. The thing that stood out to me the most was just how much the game respects the player. This game was made by people that has truly mastered their craft. There have been many moments where I found myself just progressing without following any arrows that show the way or any noticeable indicators on what to do or where to go.

A stand-out moment for me was when I had to find a quite small object in a relatively big and open area and it was under the most ordinary object and it was like the third thing I checked with a mechanic the game introduced not long before the said puzzle, I was genuinely shocked at how much the developers respected my curiosity and how little they wanted to hold my hand, I can imagine that very simple puzzle taking someone hours because they simply didn't think about doing that specific thing to that insignificant prop and having a bad impression of the game but the developers simply chose not to hold hand and let the imagination and curiosity of the players go wild.

This was a quite linear experience that felt so much open-ended than it was, a very fun sandbox with amazing puzzles and action sequences and very memorable sections, I've had a blast playing through this game, would strongly recommend anyone who's been looking for an experience that's genuinely fun and impressive.

I first played Half-Life 2 on the xbox 360 back in 2011-2012.  It came as part of the Orange Box, which I had purchased in order to play Portal.  After playing through that game a few times, I decided to try HL2 out.  It was a great experience.  Since getting into PC gaming over the last decade, I have played through it a few more times.  

Half-Life 2 is one of those canonical games; it gets to have its name mentioned in the "greatest game ever" conversations.  I'm not terribly interested in those discussions, since A) games vary so much and B) I haven't played a lot of the ones that people bring up in this connection.  

What I can say is this; Half-Life 2 has a great many virtues.  I think its best attribute is intuitive gameplay; there are so many little things that you figure out in the game, whether they are puzzle solving or combat-related, without NPCs (or, worse yet, Freeman himself) telling you what to do (this is what made me stop playing Batman: Arkham Asylum; I was sick of Bats saying things such as, "I should go through the vents."  I'm the world's greatest detective; I can figure this shit out on my own.  Why the fu-).

The game also holds up largely well from a design standpoint.  The characters look lifelike enough without falling down the uncanny valley; the style of the game's environments is fairly plain, which is fine, since this alien-dominated world would doubtless be rather drab and drear.  I think the soundtrack fits the game well, though it's not one I listen to outside the game.  

My biggest gripe with the game is the way it tells its story.  It's a good story, but it's mostly done through locking you in rooms with other characters, who exposit for a few minutes, then open the doors back up so you can go about the gameplay.  Contrast with games like Dead Space or BioShock or Deus Ex, where you are frequently contacted by people (less so in Dead Space, admittedly, but not infrequently) and come across audio/text logs that build the world.  While I appreciate that the story is all told in the game engine, having played the game through a few times, these sequences become a drag as I wait to get back to the gameplay.  

All in all, Half-Life 2 is a terrific game.  If you're into FPS games, I think it's worth playing, even if only to be able to say you played it.

The ultimate grandfather of physics-based FPS and the template for countless "cerebral" shooters. This was the "killer app" (along with Counter Strike) that truly launched Steam as a games platform. From the groundbreaking facial animations to the cryptic and alluring dystopian world, this was [b]the game[/b]. More than 20 years later, the game's stunning mechanics and clarity of vision stand as testaments to the power of focused games design and what can happen when game designers push the established boundaries.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
Two words: Gravity Gun. This singular tool/weapon changed the face of first person shooters forever and cemented Half-Life 2 as the new gold standard for single player FPS games when it released. The ability to turn environmental junk into improvised projectiles is exciting and novel in ways that audiences at the time couldn't properly articulate. This is facilitated in large part by the Source Engine's premier physics capabilities, which far surpassed Havok and other engines of the day. Swinging cranes, knocking over stacks of objects (and enemies), using floating boxes as stepping stones, flinging debris, and using balance and weight to solve puzzles was (and still is) one of the most immersive and innovative mechanics in any video game then or since.

Other weapons in the game are a delight to shoot, with a fantastically clean feel and just the right amount of kick. Certain weapons have an alt-fire mode which enhances their tactical options, and each weapon has a well-defined use-case in which it excels. From semi-auto pistols and meaty revolvers, to futuristic Combine machine guns, to (my personal favorite) the Resistance crossbow, each weapon is finely tuned and will have its own crop of fans who herald its effectiveness. Every one is adept at clearing legions of Combine soldiers, and all will need to be intelligently leveraged in order to progress.

In addition, the enemy AI was much more complex than other games of the time, with bad guys swarming, flanking, and retreating as their numbers dwindled. Gunfights are punchy, visceral affairs, and each skirmish feels unique and dire. Many times throughout the game, the player is ambushed or besieged and is forced to think on their feet, lest they be overrun. From headcrabs to Combine soldiers to striders, each new enemy type requires a new approach to beat, and will frequently see the player relying on nearby environmental factors in order to prevail. Set pieces tie seamlessly into the gameplay, and most obstacles make sense as organic parts of the game world, rather than feeling arbitrarily placed as in many other games. Levels and gameplay sections are frequently huge, and while this is mostly a great thing, there are times where these sections can drag on for far longer than they are welcome. Two notable areas in this regard are Route Kanal and Highway 17, both of which are largely vehicular in nature and feel much too long. Nova Prospekt was also a level that never seemed to end, and seemed strangely barren considering it was the point terminus for thousands of prisoners within the games own lore.

Aside from that, every level stands out as another unique portion of the arduous journey that Gordon Freeman must undergo in his mission to free humanity from the clutches of the Combine, and each level brings a design and character that is completely different from the last. The levels together paint a picture of a planet under siege, underlining the reckless destruction and oppression the Combine have visited upon the human race. From city streets to sewers, from prisons to pumping stations, and from bombed-out tenements to the Combine Citadel, each level has it's own challenges, obstacles, and feeling of upward progression. Without a doubt, this game excels at making you actually feel like [i]the[/i] Gordon Freeman. It's sublime.

[u]Story[/u]
The story of Half-Life 2 has been lauded for years as a pinnacle of writing and subtle exposition. As mentioned above, the levels themselves communicate volumes about the world and the predicament humans find themselves in, having been enslaved by a malevolent alien race after the events of the first Half-Life game. Once vibrant cities have been laid to waste, beautiful coasts and verdant fields have been destroyed from the Combine relentlessly siphoning natural resources off-world, and the human race has been oppressed, subjugated, and pushed to the brink of annihilation. Gordon Freeman has been...somewhere...since the events of Half-Life, and is transported to City 17 by the mysterious G-man to embark upon a campaign of liberation from the Combine's clutches. Alien technology abounds and fills the world with an uncomfortable, [i]assimilated[/i] feeling, and events in the game organically advance a growing sense of human resistance, struggle, and betrayal from within, such as the cold, clinical influence of Dr. Breen. One of the messages in the opening scenes of the game, "Welcome to City 17, you have chosen, or [b]been chosen[/b], to relocate to one of our finest remaining urban centers..." is written so concisely to communicate all you need to know about the situation as the player, while leaving plenty of questions to be answered. This starting piece of the puzzle is continually built upon by well-acted and well-written bits of exposition delivered by characters new and old, and leads the player to a growing sense of dread as they begin to understand how grave the situation truly is. 

As the player progresses in the game, new story bits are revealed, and the enemy response to the player's actions become ever more intense, lending a true sense of weight to the player's actions and breathing life into the world. Even in areas that feel barren and devoid of human presence, the spectre of the Combine's influence is felt and is an easy, organic justification to the palpable feeling of isolation. Gordon being labeled "anti-citizen one" is absolutely on-brand and enhances the notion that the player should not be doing what they're doing and they are not where they should be. In short, Half-Life 2 is deliciously dystopian and has established itself as a benchmark in world-building and character-driven exposition.

[u]Graphics[/u]
As a 20+ year-old game which has never seen a true remaster, the graphics in HL2 are certainly dated. [i]That said[/i], the art direction, level design, and character models really do stand the test of time. Once locked into the superb gameplay, graphics become a secondary concern, and the colors and textures still do an excellent job of conveying the needed cues. Lights illuminate the way forward, darkness delivers apprehension and a sense of unknown danger, outside scenes are overcast and feel flat (in a good way), and props are lovingly crafted and placed to create a world that has been ravaged and destroyed. At the time of the game's release, point lighting was still a premier technology, and it has been used to great effect, showcasing stark, high-contrast scenes and making flame-lit tunnels and florescent-lit hallways both pop in their own ways. Water shaders, particle effects, and debris are competent, but have been surpassed many times over by newer technology in the intervening years. Still, they get the job done, and a recent 20-year anniversary update unlocked higher display resolutions, allowed newer effects, and helped open the game to a new generation of fans. Luckily, as stated above, the game is easily able to stand on gameplay and design elements. While a remaster or complete overhaul would be welcome, the game is 100% playable as-is and is very enjoyable even without the helpful lens of nostalgia.

All in all, Half-Life 2 is a testament to incredibly robust game design and easily stands as a true video game classic. For anyone who has never played it, Half-Life 2 will lead players on a grand adventure that is as unique as it is polished. In all ways, Half-Life 2 is a game for the ages.

20 years...and still amazing. A masterpiece that deserves all those players as it defines peak tech. When I first played Half Life I was completely in awe. Not just at how amazing it was, and I mean really amazing it has had some importance, but at the alien themes present in the FPS world. Awesome stuff. And when it became more and more popular than a bumbling babbling band of baboons (you know that's really popular), we all knew that there would be a sequel. I had nightmares about how they would stuff it up like they do with so many unwanted sequels before it. That's what they do with the videogames everyone loves (and I've only seen two people who didn't like the original, and they are escaped mental patients), they do stupid cheap-ass lame sequels so that we all lose faith in the video games industry ever making anything good ever again. Thankfully, this sequel is actually very good. That's right, you heard me, you aren't hallucinating. It's actually AMAZING! It's so much fun and a great improvement over the original (like I often do consider some sequels), with outstanding graphics and awesome gameplay and characters of the essence. It does kinda start off a bit slowly, but once it gets going, and more focused on the story and actual characters start to arrive, it's non-stop thrilling and killing. Again the improved graphics are amazing and limitless and if it was awesome from the start I'd probably give it full marks, but since it takes a while to warm up, I've gotta cool its jets a bit. If you're not one of the mental patients who didn't like the original then you've probably played this already, for the rest of you give the original another chance and then go and enjoy this. It's like the first because it's a sequel.

Maybe it's just me, but I think this game is largely overrated in the modern era. Valve, as a developer, largely succeeded in the past, but they are now eclipsed by their endless failures. Counter Strike 2 was a joke. Dota Underlords was dead on arrival. Dota 2's situation is almost laughable, and Dota Artifact was sleep paralysis demon of every Triple A gaming exec. To them, it showed that taking risks and attempting to branch out was a grave mistake. It was a huge warning sign to all Triple A developers. Is risk inherently bad? No, but corporations want to mitigate risk and maximize profits. Can you blame them for their reaction to Valve's most damning failure? No. 

The funniest part about all this is that Valve's only success in the past 10-15 years has been Alyx, which is VR exclusive. Personally, I believe this was a fluke. First of all, anything HL related will succeed and be praised. It's like From Software. They could release a Dark Souls Re-Remastered and the only change could be that invaders can't heal anymore and people would still get on their hands a knees and worship Miyizaki. I choose to give them the benefit of the doubt and will assume that Alyx is a good game. Still, locking their only competent work behind a VR headset is pretty hilarious. The peasants get all the slop.

My favourite game of all time. When I played this game growing up, on the Xbox 360, it opened my eyes to what games could be, immersive narrative experiences and the idea that narrative and gameplay could be blended together fully. The physics and environmental storytelling create a very grounded world for you to meet characters and fight through, with no shortage of gameplay twists and surprises.

Each gun has its own role in your arsenal creating a tactical combat that's more thinking than just aiming. And the physics based weapons and enemies are a very unique form of combat.

The mod-ability of this game through the SDK is an experience in itself, including great community projects like [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/4000]Garry's Mod[/url], [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/362890]Black Mesa[/url] and [url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/dark-interval]Dark Interval[/url].

My big complaint is the reduced weapon and enemy variety compared to the to first game, and the abandoning of Episode Three, of course.

This is it, the greatest of all time. Now I am going to cheat a little bit and lump this review of Half Life 2 in with its 2 fantastic episodes as one package. But that package comes together as one complete piece to make, in my opinion, the greatest videogame of all time (and it was bundled all together for the anniversary patch anyway). Everything about this game is perfection - the post-Combine invaded world, the characters, the overt and environmental storytelling, the puzzles, and of course the weapons/shooting. The unique setpieces: City 17, Ravenholm, the Nova Prospekt prison, and the buildup to the Citadel itself - all iconic. Followed by the terrific episodes dealing with the fallout of the base game. All of it holds up so well 20 years later, and countless games today will probably find roots that somehow trace back to Half Life 2 in some capacity.

There is no better time to play this game than after the 20th Anniversary update which puts the game and episodes in more of a package (and check out a great youtube documentary they released as well). I’m currently working on another playthrough to listen to all the audio commentary they added, and can’t wait to just take in this game again. It is a timeless masterpiece.

"Half-Life 2" is one of the most influential and groundbreaking first-person shooters ever made. Released in 2004 by Valve, it redefined what players could expect from a video game in terms of both storytelling and gameplay. The game’s narrative is immersive, unfolding without traditional cutscenes, which allows the player to feel like they are truly part of the story. The protagonist, Gordon Freeman, is a silent hero who navigates through a dystopian world filled with alien invaders and oppressive human forces. This unique approach to storytelling pulls the player into the game’s world, making every action feel meaningful.

The physics engine in "Half-Life 2" was revolutionary for its time. The way objects interact with the environment feels natural and intuitive, and it became a major part of the gameplay. From solving puzzles using physics to creatively using the environment as a weapon, it was an innovation that influenced many games that followed. The gravity gun, which allows players to manipulate objects in real-time, is still one of the most memorable and fun weapons in gaming history.

The level design in "Half-Life 2" is another standout feature. The game introduces players to varied environments, from the dark, industrial city of City 17 to the eerie, remote marshlands. Each location feels carefully crafted, with attention to detail that makes the world feel alive. The pacing is also masterful, alternating between moments of intense combat and slower, atmospheric sequences that allow the player to soak in the environment and story.

The AI in "Half-Life 2" was also ahead of its time. Enemies behave intelligently, using cover, working together, and reacting to the player’s actions in a way that makes combat more dynamic and challenging. The enemy variety, from the terrifying Combine soldiers to the creepy headcrabs, keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The interactions with NPCs and the world around you help build a sense of tension and immersion, keeping you on edge throughout the experience.

The game's soundtrack, composed by Kelly Bailey, perfectly complements the atmosphere, using subtle but effective music to enhance both the action and the quieter moments. The sound design is top-notch, with ambient sounds adding to the immersion, whether you're in a busy city street or exploring a deserted warehouse.

Ultimately, "Half-Life 2" is a masterpiece that still holds up to this day. Its innovative gameplay, storytelling, and technical achievements make it a game that set a new standard for the industry. It’s a game that’s not just fun to play, but one that’s easy to appreciate for the way it shaped the future of video games. Even though it’s been years since its release, "Half-Life 2" remains a classic that continues to inspire both players and developers alike.

Half Life 2 is quite fun. The gunplay feels okay, and the gravity gun's introduction is great. The latter chapters are action-packed and have you fighting the various Combine troops.

Despite its pros, it has some problems:
- The AI is scuffed. I prefer HL1's AI, but I can see the Combine's appeal.
- The first levels of the game are bad. No, I don't want a vehicle section. I barely liked On A Rail.
The vehicle sections tire me out, and I often drop the game when I reach Nova Prospect.

The modding scene for this game is massive. Most people will recommend either MMOD for a revamped base game, Zero Two for a new campaign. I'm waiting for a mod called Inhuman. It's a mod where you play as a rogue Combine. If it comes out, that is.

Overall, Half Life 2 is great, and it's a solid recommend for people who loved HL1 or are interested in playing classic FPS games. However, some players may feel that the game is aged and need modding.
