When Valve were making Half-Life 2, they gave themselves one goal to start with: make a better game than [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/70/]Half-Life[/url]. The result was an influential classic that many people consider one of the finest games of all time. Whether it's the [i]literal[/i] best game ever made is up for debate, but it's certainly up there, and is definitely worth experiencing at least once.


To begin with, the game has aged remarkably well. It still looks nice (the 20th anniversary update made it look better) and plays quite intuitively for a game as old as it is, with much-improved physics over the first game thanks to the Source engine. That alone was a significant advance; even if most of the game's physics puzzles were rudimentary in comparison to later games, they were groundbreaking in 2004. The inclusion of a weapon that manipulates physical objects, the gravity gun, is lauded to this day.

The actual shooting in this FPS was never revolutionary in and of itself. It's pretty old-school these days what with no aiming down sights, and it has less cool guns than HL1, but it's still fairly satisfying. Valve's masterful grasp of pacing is displayed as enjoyable shooting sections are interstitched with traveling, puzzles and plot scenes - HL2 continues the series tradition of taking place entirely from first-person perspective. One could consider some of the beginning and endgame plot sections to be glorified cutscenes anyway, but that technique is generally used sparingly enough to justify it. It's more of a problem in the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/380/]episodic[/url] [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/420]sequels[/url].

The story pitting Gordon Freeman against the alien dictatorship of the Combine years after the events at Black Mesa has lost a bit of its bite, simply because of the fact it was released in 2004 and was more original back in its day. (Seinfeld has the same problem with its comedy.) The cultural problem, not the alien problem. It's still ultimately engaging; even if the mid-game drags at points, the majority of the game is smartly laid out and enjoyable, displaying considerable variety in both gameplay and tone that was revolutionary when it came out.


If there's criticism to be had of the story, it's that it's basically in the middle of its series. It's a continuation of Half-Life 1 that keeps going until HL2: Episode Two, which itself ends on an unresolved cliffhanger. The characters and story therefore may not be as compelling for some people if they haven't played HL1 and received the context from that game. Valve's continuing decision to eschew traditional cutscenes and give the player absolute control at all times, as well as the lack of spontaneity in combat, means that the game can get tiresome on repeat playthroughs in comparison to HL1.

While there's also something to be said for reliving those narrative scenes after years and years of not playing, it ultimately doesn't work quite as well as a narrative vehicle here as it did in the chaotic confines of the original Half-Life, where danger was seemingly around each and every corner. Gordon Freeman as a silent protagonist also doesn't quite work as well in this game, with its individually defined, designed and voice-acted supporting characters, as it did in the original game with its masses of nameless scientists and Barneys.

I'd still urge you to try this if you're a fan of shooters and you haven't already, as these criticisms are ultimately minor in the face of how good the game is overall, and of how influential it was.

Overall, Half Life 2 is a fantastic FPS that made groundbreaking technological advancements that are still incredible today, and it is still better than many modern releases.

Played the whole series for the first time, going from the original Half-Life to this one.

While Half-Life 1 can feel a little dated, I cannot say that at all about Half-Life 2 and its episodes. The game mechanics aren't just able to keep up with modern standards; they are pretty much timeless.

The gunplay itself is snappy and great, reminding me of boomer shooters such as Doom and Quake. However, the true star of the show in this game is the Gravity Gun. As the main tool for solving physics-based puzzles and engaging in combat, it gives players a lot of agency in how they approach challenges.

The quick thinking enabled by the Gravity Gun in combat situations is immensely satisfying. For example, you can throw explosive barrels at aliens or zombies, cut enemies in half with launched saw blades, and more. The game ensures players are almost never out of control and allows interaction with virtually everything in the environment, making the experience highly immersive.

It does an excellent job of trusting the player to navigate situations on their own. The map design and object placement are intuitive, making it easy to figure out how to proceed without needing constant hand-holding.

The game's big strength is letting the player experience the story through exploration and action rather than overwhelming you with exposition. When there is dialogue, it is well done and short enough to let you get back to playing the game, making the story that is provided throughout the game feel more valuable.

Overall:

Half-Life 2: 10/10
Half-Life 2 Episode One: 8/10
Half-Life 2 Episode Two: 10/10

This game is not bad by any means. I love how much charm each character has and the physics mechanics are neat, but the combat loop feels like a downgrade from half life 1. 
The pistol is useless after the first few chapters due to its horizontal recoil. 
The smg is extremely inaccurate and I only found it useful to waste ammo on headcrab-zombies (it's alt fire is still good though for AoE).
You don't get the shotgun until halfway through the game. 
You can't turn off the laser guide for the rpg, so you have to look straight at a sniper and take damage just so the rocket hits the sniper and jesus christ what a dumb design choice. 
The Tau and Guass cannon are gone, it doesn't really harm the combat loop I just miss them.
I really like the gravity gun because you can use it to pick up sawblades and other objects to throw at enemies. However you rarely get to use it much offensively since there isn't many sawblades or such objects. 
Weapons I do like are the shotgun, revolver, AR2, and crossbow since they do a lot better burst damage.
While I do like being able to control the character while in cutscenes, there is no option to skip cutscenes.
Some sections in the game last too long like the boat ride.
You move slower and can't airstrafe. At best your hops can launch you a little faster, but you can't chain hops into a bunnyhop.
And the combine ai is a little of a downgrade when compare to hecu AI.

5/10, good as a video game but disappointing as an fps game.

[h1] HAPPY 20TH ANNIVERSARY HALF LIFE 2!!! [/h1]
On November 16, 2004, Valve released the greatest gem ever.

[h2] The Beginning [/h2]
I used to play this game as a kid and I liked this game of how immersive it is.

[h2] My Perspective [/h2]
2 years after I had my Steam account & I bought all the Valve games on the launcher, I started playing Half-Life 2 & it still looks incredible playing this game, the soundtrack was great to listen to as well. 3 years after I finished the game, I also started playing episodic games and had the same feeling with Half-Life 2.

[h3] Mods [/h3]
I don't have any mods installed but I thought I wanted to add two mods that hooked me.
Raising the Bar: Redux is what Half-Life 2 would be before the final release, it looked incredible and gritty!
Half-Life 2 VR Mod is the same as Half-Life: Alyx. Immersive, and amazing!

[h3] Other [/h3]
I made a poster of Half-Life 2 & its episodic games, and it's hung in my room to this day.

[h2] Closing thoughts [/h2]
Today, I'm writing this review for the 20-year celebration of the best game of all time! [spoiler] (and also the unfortunate 20 years after the human race lost The Seven Hour War against the Combine) [/spoiler]

And again...
[h1] HAPPY 20TH ANNIVERSARY HALF LIFE 2!!! [/h1]

[h1] Edit: November 19, 2024 [/h1]
After I wrote my review, Valve updated HL2 to celebrate its 20th anniversary.
The update is bigger than the Half-Life 25th anniversary update (Eg. upscaled UI, classic graphics returned, 3 games were added to the base game; like Lost Coast, and the headline, Episode 1 & Episode 2)
I've already beaten Half-Life 2 so I'm writing this review and then I'll continue playing HL2 with Episode One & Episode Two later.

[h1] Half-Life 2 [/h1]
[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
The game plays like Half-Life, shoot many enemies or smack them with a crowbar as you can and get to the end/loading screen.

[h2] Graphics & Quality [/h2]
Half-Life 2's Source Engine has more features than its predecessor, but you already know that, but if you don't then I'll explain.
Updated textures & environments.
Ragdoll physics.
Better map design.
& realistic physics.

[h2] Story [/h2]
Half-Life 2 takes place 20 years after Half-Life 1.
The story is enjoyable to listen to. It's a story about loss and despair & twisting it into revolution through the gameplay!

[h2] Overall [/h2]
I'm rating this game 10/10. It's a really good deal for those who would want to play this masterpiece, but unfortunately, the game was free to play before Nov, 19, but it's still cheap to this day. I recommend this game if you like FPS and the story so far.
Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to play Episode One.

[h1] Edit: November 19, 2024... Again [/h1]
Half-Life 2: Episodes One & Two have the same gameplay & quality as HL2 but with Alyx on your side, so I'm just reviewing the story and that's it

[h1] Half-Life 2: Episode One [/h1]

[h2] Story [/h2]
The story is good to listen to. You and Alyx's only objective is to evacuate everyone far away from the citadel!

[h2] Overall [/h2]
Half-Life 2: Episode One is going to have a 9.6/10! It's the same experience as Half-Life 2's Story, & I'm still recommending this game like the predecessor.
Two games have been done, and now one more to go.

[h1] Edit: November 20, 2024 [/h1]

[h1] Half-Life 2: Episode Two [/h1]

[h2] Story [/h2]
This game's story is a heartbreaking experience I had played. [spoiler] Prepare for unforeseen consequences. [/spoiler]

[h2] Overall [/h2]
Half-Life 2: Episode Two deserves a 9.5/10! This second episode has some mechanics that can be tedious but can be managed if you're good at this game.

Half-Life 2: The Greatest Game Ever Made

Half-Life 2 isn’t just a game—it’s a masterpiece. From the moment you step into the oppressive world of City 17, you’re hooked. The story unfolds naturally, without forced cutscenes, and every detail of the environment feels alive.

The gameplay is a perfect mix of intense combat, clever puzzles, and exploration. And the Gravity Gun? A game-changer. It’s not just a weapon; it’s a tool that makes you think creatively about every encounter.

Even years later, Half-Life 2 still looks and feels amazing. The characters, especially Alyx Vance, are unforgettable, and the world-building is unmatched. It’s the kind of game that sticks with you long after you finish.

If you haven’t played it yet, you’re missing out on a piece of gaming history. Go grab a crowbar and see why Half-Life 2 is still the gold standard.

Playing Half-Life 2 after almost 20 years and still finding it unforgettable says everything about its timeless quality. It's a game that just doesn’t age—pure perfection, then and now!

Half-Life 2 is a timeless classic. A masterful blend of immersive storytelling, combat, puzzles and exploration. Even twenty years later, it all holds up remarkably well. If you haven’t played it yet, you’re missing out on an important piece of gaming history.

This game is still the best 20 years later. Really enjoying the 20th anniversary update with all the bug fixes and improvements. I am enjoying this on my 65 inch LG C4 OLED in 4K and HDR enabled. I have a mediocre computer and can get everything in 4K, 60 HZ with no hitches with a Ryzen 3700X, an RX 5700 XT Nitro plus, and have no complaints.  I can also run it at 1440P at 120 HZ, but I enjoy the extra clarity 4K brings. The game play is still a masterclass and still worthy of praise. I have beaten game countless times, and yet it's one of those games where you can come back to it over and over again through the years. If you haven't played through the Half Life series start with Half Life 1, and if the graphics rub you the wrong way, then try Black Mesa instead, then come back to this game and enjoy the timeless game play, puzzles, and story line. It doesn't get any better than this.

It's Half-Life 2. 
You're on Steam. 
If this isn't in your library, you're doing it wrong. 
Should go without saying this is another "I fucking love this game" badge winner. 

At the time of its release, there was a lot of innovation and revolutionary game design here. The amount of objects in the world the player could interact with, and the expressions of characters, just really, really groundbreaking innovating revolutionary stuff in 2004 that blew everyone's minds away, and could really immerse you and make you feel like you're in the game world. 

Things like this have set the bar so high that even 20 years later, this is a much better developed & better playing game than many modern games today. 

Of course, it's from a different, golden age, where gaming was more stigmatized, less popular,  less of a huge industry that it is today, and game development was more centered around making the best final product possible, before 'early access' or live service games or DLC's, etc.. 

But still. 

Now, after watching the 20th Anniversary Documentary, it's crazy to think of all the ways this game almost didn't get made or released. 

Reasons to buy and play this game: 

- It easily makes lists of one of the best games ever made. What is it, something like, 39 game of the year related awards? And an original story.
Set the bar for FPS for a generation or two. Often feels like Matrix-type action. 

- Update: There are a lot of great mods... the original Substance v0.84 is a diehard favorite for me, I always try to emulate the feel that weapon-set gave...but there are many great alternatives I discuss below. 'Synergy' is a good favorite option lately. 

- Lots of fun and amusing moments, good storytelling through a game. The level design and puzzles are really great. 

- Half Life 2: Update is a free mod/update for the game that works really well and has all the achievements and it really does make the graphics look a good deal better, AI seems smoother too sometimes, definitely improves the experience, making the game more immersive, and suspension of disbelief alot more tolerable, improving the story and gameplay. The lighting and reflections are great and much more realistic. 

- Deathmatch Tactical 1.2 is an awesome frigin' mod with the best substance weapons, and bullet time, it's freaking great, you can switch between tactical and substance modes, spawn all the weapons/ammo without using impulse_101, spawn extra enemies, sniper and crossbow have scopes, and the combine and blood effects look awesome. 

- Garry's Mod automatically loads Half-Life 2 maps if you have HL2 installed, so you can play through the entire campaign co-op, or with a portal gun, custom weapons, etc. etc. to your hearts content. 

- Cinematic Mod is another awesome mod, and all these mods have their own shortcuts by the way, meaning you can have all these versions of the game to play whenever you want and they wont interfere with each other. Cinematic mod also upgrades the graphics and changes the way the weapons look and act in some cool ways. Deathmatch Tactical and CM both have aiming down the sights for example. CM enables many changes that you can customize, including harder difficulty (always lethal headshots). 

- All the HL2 games and Black Mesa have good soundtracks and great memorable gameplay moments that are epic to behold the first time and subsequent times after. 

I definitely recommend this game. If you've never seen, heard of, or played this game, buy it and play it now!!! And I would recommend playing Half Life 2: Update!

I hope my review helped inform and give ideas to others as to the best ways to experience this game of legends.

I bought the Half-Life Complete BUNDLE for only 3,66€ and it was the best purchase on Steam.
It's one of the best FPS to this day and the Episodes were equally interesting experiences for me (mainly thanks to Alyx).

It can run without Steam (right from the USB drive if you wish - it has [b]no[/b] DRM), doesn't need a powerful PC, still looks decent and has a very entertaining gameplay to this day.

› I like all the characters, and especially Alyx - I haven't expected to meet such a great character before I started playing HL2
› Weapons variety and behavior
› The game gives me a unique vibe, especially while travelling alone in chapters like Ravenholm or Highway 17, that I didn't get from any other game (Metro 2033 being a close second)
› There's something special about the Source engine, that makes me like the ambience and graphics of this game more than for example many more advanced games from recent years.

Half-Life 2 has always been a masterpiece, but with its recent update and accompanying documentary, the game feels like a modernized love letter to both its legacy and its enduring fanbase. The documentary serves as an incredible companion piece, offering behind-the-scenes insights into Valve's design philosophy and the cultural impact of Half-Life 2. It adds depth to an already beloved game, allowing fans to appreciate the artistry and innovation that went into creating it.

This update not only reinforces why Half-Life 2 is one of the greatest games of all time but also ensures that it remains relevant and accessible to new generations of players. Whether you're revisiting it or playing it for the first time, the updated Half-Life 2 is nothing short of extraordinary.

I remember watching the first videos showcasing the tech running Half-Life 2 with my friend back in 2003 or 2004. Wood never splintered in such glorious fashion, barrels never rolled like that before and the folding mattress, oh the splendour of the folding mattress... Needless to say it was something to look forward to.

I played the game back then and I did it again now, 20 years later. I could remember why this was revolutionary in 2004. It had been attempted before (Trespasser, Hitman), but physics came in like a wrecking ball this time. The way you could manipulate objects was fun and new, but most importantly, the action received a facelift that kept combat fresh and exciting from start to finish.

I played on the hardest difficulty which did something I don't like - it turned enemies far spongier. I don't mind that the enemies do more damage, but if my weapons are turned into peashooters, that's the wrong way to add difficulty. In an FPS, you want the guns to be punchy and powerful, so if you're reading this, do what I did. Set the difficulty to the highest, but add sk_dmg_inflict_scale3 "5.00" to autoexec.cfg at Half-Life 2/hl2/cfg and now the guns actually do something. Small tweak but made reliving the memories that much more fun. Game's only about 10 hours long so if you haven't had the experience, for a literal bargain you can do it now.

The ending is bad just like Xen was in Half-Life 1, but 95% of what precedes it makes it all worth it. Episode One is not great because it spends too much time back in the Citadel, but Episode Two brought back much of what made Half-Life 2 good.
Always wanted to get all these achievements again. Hard to believe it's been 11 years since my last run. It's good to be back lol

This Game gets a 9/10 from me, read the full review here:

 An amazing game, with amazing gameplay, story, and presentation made by people that were passionate about the capabilities of what video games could do mechanically and how they could tell a story! Half-Life 2 needs no introduction! Both it and its original first installment were revolutionary titles that showed how video games are made, how they form the design of the game to feel like a breathing real world, and how they pace themselves to create a captivating narrative filled with mystery. Half-Life walked so other games could run. There are many things from Half-Life that ended up being crucial lessons for a video game's designs, including physics and enemy behavior, which were not introduced just to be innovative but took complete advantage of to form a satisfying and engaging gameplay. The story is also well written, continuing the Lovecraftian story of the first game but combined with a classic dystopian setting inspired by the 1984 novel, but how the story is told through natural character interactions, environmental details, and the overall pacing of the game makes Half-Life's narrative gripping every single second! I recommend this game with all the trust, especially now that if you buy the game, you will get the episodes as well. It's a phenomenal game that deserves respect for the things that it has done!

-Physics, I mean breaking glass, moving boxes and ragdolls and more still holds up to this day if not better then most stuff nowadays

-Secrets, so well done in this game
-Characters are super memorable and natrual, voice acting is top notch
-Story.... I dont wanna go on here cause itll take me to create a scroll here truly, just say the plot is simple and easy to understand while the lore is complex and fascinating. One of the best story lines in video games.
-And finally replayability. IDK why but this game is SOO replayable, it just fails to be boring, Im not sure its because the lack of cutscenes and physics, or because its soo fun it doesnt gets old, but it doesnt get old.

Cons:
-Not so friendly to people who arent used to these types of games, when I first reviewed this I yapped on how everything feels crancky and unnatrual so you can take from that
-Shooting, is not that good, enemies have very little knockback and some weapons are quite crancky, it aint that bad tho, the weapons design is interesting tho, just quiet rough in practice.
-And in general the combat is a little rough with hit scanners and all
-Achievement are a pain in the ass in this game I guess
-There are some gimmicks that work worse then others

[h1]Rating: 10/10 -Masterpiece[/h1]

[h1]TLDR:[/h1]
[b]This is the peak of the linear story driven FPS genre. Absolute player freedom.[/b]


This is probably the most legendary game on the platform that still holds up to this day. I could play this game over and over again. This game is as old as me.


[h1]Positive:[/h1]

[b]Story:[/b]
The story continues. Freeman is brought back from stasis and now has to face the Combine. An alien race that came from Zen and invaded earth in just 7 hours. It's now your job to support the human resistance and kick their ass back to Zen. This is easier said than done

[b]Characters:[/b]
You can't save earth on your own. You will meet eli vance and his daughter alyx which welcome you to help the resistance. You will be on your own most of the time but you will meet other people and groups that will help you in certain situations.

[b]World:[/b]
The game starts out in an east european inspired place called "city 17". You will traverse diverent places throughout the game. Shores, tunnels and streets of city 17. You will use vehicles in certain parts. The world is filled with secret supplies only attentive players will find.

[b]Physics:[/b]
The physics were revolutionary back then. It's still cool today. Everything is interactable and throwable. Sometimes even destructable. The ragdolls flying never gets old.

[b]Player freedom:[/b]
The lack of cutscenes that take control away from the player is refreshing. It's up to you if you want to pay attention to the story or rather play around in the room. You can decide if you want to explore every room and house or if you just want to drive by it, potentially missing out on loot that could help you later. We all play the same game but everyone plays different.

[b]Music:[/b]
The music is really good just like the first one. In fact, it reuses some of the tracks from the first game. I love the synth atmosphere tracks so much. It's even got some music that sounds like the 90's or 00's (because it is).

[b]Graphics:[/b]
I did a review of the first game and criticised the graphics because of how ugly that game can look. I will say it again. I really don't care about graphics at all and I put gameplay over everything but HL1 hurt to look at im sorry. In HL2's case. I want to praise the graphics. This is hands down the best looking game from 2004. Nothing comes close to it. It's insane how good it still looks 20 years later.


[h1]Negative:[/h1]

[b]None:[/b]
This game is flawless. There is nothing that should be added or removed. (The MP7 sound makes my ears bleed but the game is worth it).


[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

I've played this game multiple times. Vanilla and modded. I've collected all achievements and in the episodes too. This is what a real video game should be. It's a one and done experience that is so good that you want to play it over and over again.

This isn't the case for half life 2 because no one has been able to improve or even replicate it. Half Life 2 was incredible when it came out and it is incredible now. To this day there is not really anything like it out there.  You have chosen, or been chosen, to relocate to one of our finest remaining urban centers. the best game of 2004

The older I get, the more I appreciate the Half-Life games and their monumental impact on the first-person shooter genre. Revisiting Half-Life 2 for its 20th anniversary—after a decade since first completing Episode 2—has only solidified its place as my favourite game of all time.

Despite hearing close friends dismiss Half-Life as "terrible," "irrelevant," or "hAlF lIfE HaS wRiTeRs?" (marcel)  playing through the series again reminded me of its brilliance. The immersive world-building, revolutionary physics, Kelly Bailey’s unforgettable soundtrack, the chilling ambient noises, and believable characters create a gaming experience that remains unmatched.

If you’ve never given Half-Life a chance, I urge you to do so. Yes, it may lack modern-day dopamine hits like flashy cosmetics, instant rewards, and flashy bright colours, but for those willing to explore its environments and absorb its narrative, Half-Life offers a depth and immersion rarely found in today's gaming landscape.

2019: HL2 is astounding. The HL series is to games what the original Star Wars trilogy is to film. I just beat HL2 for the first time in 10 years, on hard this time, and oh my word. While it's not the best game ever as some people think, it was an absolutely joyous experience. A bit of a slow burner for the first few chapters, but that is really the only non-nitpick criticism I have. The amount of little tiny details that went into this game is astounding even today.

May I also mention the soundtrack to die for? Kelly Bailey, you brilliant, brilliant man.

2024: Sure, any excuse to play this again. The parts where it locks you in rooms with talking NPCs can go though. Please. Add a skip button.
After playing it again: In the space of 5 years, HL2's themes have become more relevant than ever. They hit HARD.

Innovation is an essential part of all Half-Life games and I can only hope- no, EXPECT- some innovation from whatever Valve has been cooking up for the past few years. It will certainly bring- unforeseen consequences, hm?

Probably one of the biggest disappointments in gaming history. Good? Yes, excellent level design, even though a couple (route kanal and the whole street fighting section) were rage inducing even back then. What I mostly dislike about HL2 which I have played very little compared to HL1, is that 99% of the promo material came from the beta which looked, sounded and behaved much better. I bought the game back in 2004 convinced that I would get the same atmosphere and feel of the beta, when none of that was preserved. It felt like a happy-go-lucky version of what HL2 was supposed to be, complete with memetic power and very bright skyboxes. In terms of story and pacing, what raising the bar showed was immensely more appealing,  the levels at the end of the day were the biggest offenders, incredibly less interesting to look at than the promo material. Here's generic eastern european city with some alien tech. No air exchange mega structures, no semi-fascist architecture, way less oppressive and not in line with what HL1 was going to show.
Also I will never get over how broken the Source engine was. What a mess of an engine, the stuttering, the endless loading, the crashes, HL2 on release was swiss cheese, holes upon holes for months on end. The fact that the levels do not stutter after loading in 2024 is amazing. Kids these days will never know the struggle.

The first weapon in the game that you get is a crowbar, which helped me out a lot the whole game, with its help you can fill up a couple of headcrabs or a gawking enemy. The arsenal is small, but quite sufficient in power. I liked, for example, to nail someone to the wall with a crossbow. And how I messed around when I came across a gravity cannon, everything flew from me to the enemies from various boxes and balloons to grenades that they threw at me, and there are also sharp discs-blades with which you could saw zombies. What also impressed me was the opportunity to set huge ants on the enemy using their queen's pheromones.
In general, if you have not played this game, then be sure to play it, I doubt that someone will not like it.

[b]Half-Life 2[/b] is one of the best storytelling games I've ever played. It still stands out in the modern gaming landscape due to its innovative execution. For its time, it was a ground breaker in terms of its graphics and physics, and proved that it is not only possible to create a fun and balanced gaming experience that suits a wide range of gaming styles, but also create an impact with its engaging and realistic character design. Combined [i](pun intended)[/i] with its captivating and endlessly cruel dystopian universe and subtle, often visual storytelling, the result is nothing short of impressive.

Pros:
+ Very good story
+ Creative game play
+ Many things to explore
+ No grinding (unless you hunt for achievements)
+ Developer still care and update this game
+ Very cheap price

Cons:
+ Somewhat outdated engine
+ Unfinished story

[h1]It’s Time To Save The World![/h1]
Like the original Half-Life (1998), Half-Life 2 combines shooting, puzzles, and storytelling, and adds features such as vehicles and physics-based gameplay. Players control Gordon Freeman as he joins a resistance movement to liberate the Earth from the control of a multidimensional alien empire, the Combine.

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ATReviews]Follow My Review Group Here![/url]

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Half Life 2 has really impressive graphics for its age. Environments are well designed and the atmosphere is absolutely impressive. The game looks really sharp and has incredible physics with even some destruction. The whole atmosphere is just so immersive, especially the beginning part of the game. Many sections look unique from each other and the enemies all look both terrifying, and really cool!. Character animations are honestly mind blowing for a game made in 2004. I wasn’t expecting the amount of detail in the facial animations. The UI is really simple, but it works perfectly here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]So many great things to say here. Let’s start with the good points. I love how interactable the environment is. This plays a big role in puzzle solving and it delivers perfectly. Many of the puzzles are satisfying to solve and some even have rewards like ammo and health. I enjoyed every puzzle this game offered and never felt disappointed. The enemies are just incredible! You have a wide range of enemy types. You have many different soldiers to fight against with their own gadgets, and many creatures that will cause you many headaches and nightmares. The weapon variety is really good but one weapon stands above all, and that’s the gravity gun! The gravity gun will play a huge role in puzzles, and can be a deadly weapon against anyone. You can hold on to almost any item in the game and shoot at anyone. Items can be barrels, cans, boxes, explosives, and much more. This gives you much freedom and makes the gameplay loop much more enjoyable. The level design is superb! Many cool locations with even some horror sections to keep the game interesting and mysterious at times. The game does have some flaws though. One big one is the movement. Sometimes objects on the ground will just stop you from moving completely. This is frustrating when you are doing a puzzle or trying to move quickly in tight areas. It doesn’t happen all the time, but when it does it sucks. The companions you get later into the game are trash. I can’t stand them with a passion. They will block you in doorways and just ride you from behind. The companions do more harm than good for the most part. I feel like I would have done better without them. Overall the game has amazing features and mechanics that were revolutionary for the time and still hold up fairly well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story was just fantastic! Saving the world from Aliens never really gets old. Seeing the world filled with corruption and drained of natural resources was pretty unique. You will encounter many incredible moments and some twists as well. The whole game felt like one big movie. No abrupt cutscene, just everything happening in real time. You will get immersed with the story and world of Half Life 2. A linear story, but a great story nonetheless. Can you save humanity in time? That’s all up to you![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]The game is around 15+ hours with good pacing. That's just the main story! You also have the amazing expansions packs to play, along with a ton of mods in the Steam Workshop! Half Life 2 has great replayability, especially with the amazing mod support.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is really good. Nothing groundbreaking, but it gets the job done. The game has some pretty good soundtracks as well. The voice acting is actually impressive. Everyone did their job so well and made many scenes both believable and movie like (especially for 2004). One issue I had was that you can increase the dialogue sound separately from the game. You can only change the game and music volume. Some sections make the dialogue really hard to hear and it was pretty frustrating.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really had any serious bugs or issues. One minor graphical bug but that was really it. It's a Valve game so they always tend to have games with such little bugs and issues.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The performance is really good. Max settings with no issues with frame rate or stutters. The game was flawless from start to finish. I know back then this game was a chore to run, but if you have a modern rig you will be fine.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Steam Workshop
[*]Many cool locations
[*]Fantastic puzzles
[*]Amazing level design
[*]Incredible story telling
[*]Great attention to detail
[*]Voice acting is really good
[*]Fun weapons and gadgets
[*]Amazing graphics for the time
[*]Environmental storytelling
[*]Many fun rewarding secrets
[*]Gunplay is solid and responsive
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Movement feels clunky at times
[*]Companions are dumb and become a nuisance
[*]Minor audio issues (reloading sound effect not working at times)
[*]Can’t increase the dialogue audio specifically (it’s only game audio or music)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]9/10
This game is worth full price![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Half Life 2 is well known for all the right reasons. With nonstop action and a quest to save the world, the game was just full of incredible moments and twists. This game feels so ahead of its time and I’m happy to say that the hype is real here. I wouldn’t say it’s a 10/10 since it does have some issues and frustrations, but it’s fairly close to that perfect score. If you love sci fi games and looking for a good story, then you have to pick this up![/td]
    [/tr]

Now that we are finaly able to get the uncensored version in germany i played through Half Life 2 over the past few days to see if it would change my opinion on the game. It really didnt, i still think that HL2 is a fine game, and while the textures and models are definitly 20 years old, the lightling is still superb. 

However for the gameplay my opinion is a bit more varied. While i do like certain parts of the campaign, the overall leveldesign, as well as enemy variety is a bit lacking compared to Half Life 1. You get the last really meaningful weapon after 5 hours, and thats only half way through the game, at which point most encounters feel like you just fight the same enemies with the same weapons. The original HL mixed alien and soldiers, together with an very claustrophic envoirment. HL2 on the other hand removes more and more aliens, in the end you fight mostly combine soldiers, with maybe a few striders. Im also not very fond of the driving sections, tho i know that alot of ppl like em so i guess it was the right decision from valve to put them in here, theyre just not for me.

Despite my problems with the game i still find it impossible to not recommend playing through it at least once. Especially nowadays, where you can get for super cheap and sometimes even free.

20 years. I wasn't there since day one but I was ever since the Orange Box back in 2007. Honestly what's there to be said about Half Life 2 that wasn't already said? The fact that you're even here means you have at least heard of what it did for the gaming industry. I think everybody needs to play Half Life 2 at least once in their lives because this really is a game that changes your perspective on fps games and video games in general.
Other games of the time that need to be remastered with mods or otherwise in order to be able to be played in an acceptable state nowadays. However, Half Life 2 doesn't need any of that and honestly it doesn't feel dated in any way in my eyes. That's why I always push back on the idea that it's a "boomer shooter". It's not a game just for the people who played it back in the day and are nostalgic about it. The added features that were added on the anniversary update, like the workshop, are the cherry on top. Yeah, the shooting and gunplay is a bit "vanilla" now but that's because of how monumental it was at the time which caused every future Valve fps game, and many non Valve games, to either literally build off it or copy it. 
After you're done with it might I recommend playing Synergy, which allows you to play the campaign online with others. Even though it wasn't build for more than one player the dumb fun you can have with it is crazy. Anyway, launch it and play as you're listening to the 2 hour documentary. 
Speaking of which, near the end of the documentary it's finally revealed that Episode 3 was in the works only for 6 months and that Valve abandoned it to work on Left 4 Dead. It's incredibly tragic and even the devs said that this was a mistake and that they should have gone back to it. However, later on Gabe says that shipping Half Life 3 is Valve's obligation towards gamers. To me this means that HL3 is not only in active development but that we'll most definitely see it soon enough.

Edit: 10 years later i'm updating my review. I'm 24 now and Half-Life 2 continues to be one of my most favorite games of all time. I play through Half-Life 1, Half-Life 2, and the episodes each 1 or 2 times every year and they truly never get old to me. Every time I play through the games I get sucked in to the story all over again and I become obsessed until the cycle repeats again in a few months. Although I have been upset with Valve in recent years, convinced that they have lost their touch and no longer have the soul they had when making the Half-Life games, I was pleasantly surprised by the 20th Anniversary update and it made me remember how much respect I still have for them and of the countless hours of enjoyment they have given me with their games. If you have never played the games before I'm here to tell you firsthand that it isn't a game that you will want to miss and even after all of this time the graphics, gameplay, and story still hold up just as well as they did back in 2004. I can't wait to get my hands on the new release of Raising the Bar and I wish I could personally show Valve and the whole Half-Life team how much of a dedicated fan I am. Here's hoping for the future of Half-Life! Despite whether the game is truly done or not, it will never die in my heart.

After the 20th Anniversary update from Valve, I dabbled with HL2, replaying through a few chapters. The takeaway is that HL2 is still so damn good, I love it. It's super nostalgic and the game design is enduring. It's really just one impressive level after another and the really cool thing is that the developers are always switching up the formula in little ways. There are chase sequences, horror atmospheres, vehicle-centric levels, interactive story bits, shoot-outs, platforming, puzzle solving, physics shenanigans, and more. The variety is thoughtful too as everything is taught very subtly as to not interrupt the flow of the game. There's nothing quite like Half-Life 2.
After all these years, still amazing!

Just finished my first replay of the base game and both episodes since playing them on the orange box more than 10 years ago. Really happy to say that the whole package holds up all this time later. A really one of a kind experience that hasn't really had much competition in its space due to just how unique it is. 

The physics are easily one of my favourite things about the games. The way you have to approach puzzles and sometimes combat by utilising bits of the environment is just amazing. And certain scenes looks incredible even to this day, Like the bridge scene in episode 2.

However after finishing the story for now and having previously played Alyx I just want to have some kind of conclusion to the story as it feels like not much is resolved by the end of what we currently have. I really hope that Valve continue this franchise after this agonisingly long hiatus

The story is very captivating and beautiful, every time I re-play this game It feels like brand new. The combat and physics mechanics of the source game engine are one of the best and most satisfying ones to ever be made.

With the 20th anniversary update to the game now you have access to the Steam Workshop which is filled to the brim with endless mods that either alter the base game, making It more entertaining, fun, challenging or outright hilarious, you can also download entire new community made campaigns, some of which stand up in terms of quality on par with the base game, they are incredible.

The game is also very polished, and very fast, since It was released 20 years ago, but still feels like new all this time after.

And from my experience, you can get very attached to this universe and the characters in the game, which kind of makes me sad there is no more official content after finishing the game, but there isn't anything Valve can do about this.

In any case the game is perfect as is and is one of the best games to have ever been made! Worth It! 10/10

Half-Life 2 is an incredible, story-rich first person shooter game featuring an interactive and innovative physics engine that still holds merit even 20 years after its initial release. Interactions with NPCs feel natural and dynamic. Due to the absence of cutscenes that remove control from the player, you remain fully immersed in the dialogue and the way that the environment changes and reacts around you, with the ability to walk around freely and observe the world how you choose. 

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys first person shooters that tell a story while delivering incredible action sequences.

I was intrigued by the news that HL2 has gotten an update to celebrate its 20th anniversary, so I gave it another go. I wasn't expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised. The textures seem a little better, but there are a few new wrinkles that, to my eye, weren't in the earlier version. The zombie behavior, especially the fast zombies in Ravenholm, seemed a little more lively, I saw Civil Protection officers launch manhacks. I'm only partway through it, but it's well worth a replay, and well worth buying and giving it a whirl, especially at the seasonal sale price. It's a classic and has aged very well.
Man of Few words

This game, well half life as a whole is misunderstood in my opinion. Half life chose to tell a story in a way that you rarely see games nowadays do, that being "trying to create the illusion that you were not playing an interactive movie. and rather that you were the one in the story not your player character. How does it achieve that? Well first off Gordon Freeman is entirely silent and there are no cut-scenes. If Gordon wasn't silent then his opinions might differ from yours and take you out of your immersion and the lack of cutscenes makes it feel like actual real time events and not simply a before stated "interactive movie." If a character is talking you don't feel like their talking to Gordon you feel like their talking to YOU, and you will often find yourself talking back to characters which makes you connect with them more. That might sound a little embarissing but it really helps to make the experiance much more enjoyable.

I will probably add more to this review but I'm tired so goodbye.

Half-Life 2 is the game that made me realize that physics can be more fun than I ever thought possible. I mean, where else can you solve puzzles by launching furniture, shoot a gravity gun at a bunch of exploding barrels, and have it all make perfect sense? From the moment you step into the boots of Gordon Freeman, the quietest hero in gaming history (who still manages to save the world, without saying a single word), you’re hooked. The game’s world is beautifully crafted, and you can’t help but laugh when you accidentally launch a couch at an enemy, sending them flying like they just got hit by a truck. It’s physics-based chaos, and I’m here for it. And let’s not even get started on the zombies—because what would a post-apocalyptic world be without them, right? These zombies don’t just shuffle around aimlessly; they make you question your entire existence as you try to outsmart them.

At its core, Half-Life 2 is a first-person shooter set in a dystopian world where you, as Gordon Freeman, have to fight off alien invaders, a brutal totalitarian regime, and, of course, hordes of terrifying zombies. The game introduces a fascinating mix of intense combat, problem-solving, and exploration. What sets it apart from most shooters is the inclusion of the gravity gun, which lets you pick up, throw, and manipulate objects in the environment—turning anything from a box of nails to a vending machine into a weapon. The physics engine is a game-changer, allowing for creative solutions to problems, whether it’s building a bridge out of debris or solving environmental puzzles. The story is rich, with a deep narrative that gradually reveals the secrets of the mysterious Combine forces that have taken over Earth. It’s an unforgettable experience that is immersive, suspenseful, and—most importantly—fun.

But what really makes Half-Life 2 stand the test of time is its unmatched atmosphere. The game is visually stunning for its age, with environments that range from eerie, fog-filled canals to the grim, industrialized city of City 17. The sense of isolation and oppression is palpable, and you can feel the weight of Freeman’s journey as you fight through level after level. The AI is surprisingly advanced for its time, and it’s not just about blasting your way through enemies—strategizing with the environment and using your resources wisely is key. If you’re into story-driven first-person shooters with a mix of physics-based puzzles, action, and a narrative that leaves you thinking long after the game ends, Half-Life 2 is a must-play. Whether you’re a fan of the genre or looking for a classic that still holds up, this game is an absolute gem. Trust me, you’ll be launching more than just couches after you get your hands on that gravity gun.

I've got to say this has to be one of the best games I've ever played. It is such a fun game and the story is absolutely incredible. I'd say that Half-Life 1 is the game that sets up the plot for what will effect the world and Half-Life 2's base game explores more of a world building aspect on how the world was effected by the Combine. Episodes 1 and 2 expand more on the overarching story and I have to say it is incredible. I have not played Half-Life Alyx, but if and when I get myself a PCVR, it will be the first game I play on it. I am now in the wait and wonder for and of Half-Life 3. This story deserves to be expanded upon and I can't wait to be there for when it does. It was an absolute honor to have this game series be the final games I played for 2024 and first series I finished in 2025.

I have one criticism though. Not enough Barney, NEVER enough Barney.

Half life 2 is a worthy sequel to a masterpiece of a game and is a masterpiece in itself. This kinda story is a love letter to sci-fi enthusiasts like me, there's not a lot of stories out there that gets me going like this one does. I still find myself scrounging the internet for more of its hidden lore. I loved the game world, the characters, the revolutionary graphics and physics based game play for the time. I have nothing bad to say about this game.

[h3](Overall Rating- 4.8/5)[/h3]

20 years later since this game was released in 2004 I just have the opportunity to play it for first time. And I was really surprised that this game for me is not that old, in fact I think some feature are still new even for now. It answered many question for me when I was young that why it is one of the greatest game of all time. 

The game has a unique way to presented the dystopia world to the player. They show you what a world would look like if the alien that really powerful have arrived by kicked you into the middle of chaos situation in City-17. Behind every action form every character in this game have a reason and consequence. And it also for the player too. 

Half-Life 2 gameplay have no minimap, no cut scene, no guideline or objective...and also no bitches. You need to explore the map, learn mechanic in game especially the physic which is the main gameplay, listen to the hint that hide in conversation between you and the NPC and decide your own way go through the game. Every moment or situation that happened in game will let you join and your action will effected to them too.

Mobs and enemies in this game also very challenge when you have to face it. The soldier or combine have a tactics to get over you. they can learn your action and adapt to use it against player. The alien or zombies also have it's own mechanic. So you need to learn their strengths and weaknesses, and use the right weapon to fight them more effective. Physic in game also related to the mobs, if you learn to use it will make gameplay more fun and challenge. If you play like no thought-head empty, these mobs can easily get you annoyed or triggered (cuz i tried it before).

Half-Life 2 Graphic, atmosphere and sceneries are very majestic even some features are outdated now but with a game which is 20 years old now (it's even older than me) for me it not that bad compare to it time. The sound design, mood, music, dialogues are in line with the theme of the game. It can explain to you what is happened in that places and how do you get involved with it without a single word. It's make player felt like they're a part of the game.

After all the reason, for me Half-Life 2 is worth to play once in your lifetime. even it also have a bad sides such as some bugs that can ruined the game and because it's an old game some feature are not up to date. Also with design game with no guideline or anything that can lead you to the next path sometime can make you stuck in the scene or place for a while and easily get you bored (especially me who don't understand English much because it's not my native language cause me to walk around and don't know which way to go) but all in all is a very great game for me. Worth my expectation as one of the great FPS game of all time as people said, even 20 year have already passed and since I've Known the game name Half-Life 2.

John Freeman who was Gordon Freemans brother was one day in an office typing on a computer. He got an email from his brother that said that aliens and monsters were attacking his place and aksed him for help so he went.

John Freeman got his computer shut down and wet on the platform to go up to the roof of the building where he left his motorcycle and normal people close because he was in his office lab coat. John Freeman got on his motorcycl and said "its time for me to live up to my family name and face full life consequences" so he had to go.

John Freeman ramped off the building and did a backflip and landed. He kept driving down the road and made sure there was no zombies around because he ddint have weapon.

The contrysides were nice and the plants were singing and the birds and the sun was almost down from the top of the sky. the mood was set for John Freemans quest to help his brother where he was. Pros:
 - Has more life and soul than AAA games.
 - Seamless Environmental puzzles that make you feel big brain.
 - Valve immersion at its best, tutorial so good its not even a tutorial.
 - Genius level design.
 - Good main story.
 - Cosmic and Lovecraftian horror elements in its ambiguous storytelling.
 - Can probably run on an actual potato at 1440x900 resolution.
 - The Freeman Man
 - SV_CHEATS 1
 - Mindblowing interactivity for a seemingly indie game made in 2004.
 - Genuinely competent AI(once you play around with it).
 - Full Modding support.
 - Has a community that upholds thousands of mods, such as campaigns(Entropy Zero 2, Minerva, Swelter etc.) and game improvements and changes.
 - Steam Workshop... need I say more?
 - Comes with both expansions to the base game, Episode 1 & 2.

Cons:
 - The TD sections are kinda mid.
 - The community ranges from nice to toxic.
 - Episode 1 is fine, but somewhat of a drop in quality.
 - This is only 10 dollars...

After finally playing both HL2, HL2E1, and HL2E2. There are a lot of things I gotta say.

Half-Life 2;

The great:
I love how that a ton of the places you go to in HL2 feel well developed and alive, there's a lot of things to look at and find, this which helps the gameplay as if you care for just going in one path quickly, you can! But if you want to take it slow and explore, you are allowed to do that too! There's a lot of things for anything to enjoy!

The meh:
While yes I did just say how good the gameplay is there is some areas that just give a, ugh, feeling while coming back to them. In example: Some of Water Hazard and Highway 17 are a little boring to play but those boring parts go by quickly so it's not that bad.

Half-Life 2 is overall for me a beautiful: 10/10


After the success of HL2, Valve created Episode 1, which tells more of the story about what happens after the ending of HL2.

The Great: 
Despite this game being quite short, it still is good. I love the way the have you co-op with Alyx and how much they do well with that idea. The final area is also really fun and also it has the best joke in the whole Half-Life series. Zombine.

The Meh:
Honestly, I did not have any bad to say about EP.1.

Half-Life 2: EP.1 is overall, once again, for me is: 10/10


You know what's next, EP.2

The Great:
The big thing about this expansion is that you get to travel with Alyx and get to launch a rocket. This game is also honestly quite fun. I love that is now is wanting you to do more exploring type gameplay then combat. That doesnt mean its all explorer type gameplay. When there is big combat sections it's awesome here.

The Meh:
The 'Get Some Grub' Achievement is quite annoying but that's all I have to say about EP.2

Half-Life 2: EP.2: 10/10

This is one of the greatest  games  ever made. Many years ago on the Xbox 360 I played all the Half-life 2 games well over 10  times and  got  100% of achievements. Now, on this busted up computer that stutters sound and visual every 2 minutes, I have 100% on too. It's that great of a series that persevered through the bullshit of my machine not working so I could gain all the achievements. Because  I love this game so much. It's an almost perfect game and sequel to me  and now you get it and the episodes all in one purchase  outside of the orange box.

I'm not really writing this review to sell you on Half-life 2. It's more so for me. Everybody knows the Half-life series is incredible already. The only reason someone is reading this is because they love these games too and want to see that admiration in others. 

What I love about Half-life 2 is that it takes the way the first game presented storytelling and  only  amplified it. No cutscenes except for the scenes  with Gman and when you meet Alyx for the first time. Both of which, do not take up enough time to make you think "Just let me play". The story is always happening around you in gameplay and I love that. There's no point at which they tell you that Striders are not just robots with mounted guns, they're bio-mechanical. The game always shows you. It shows you the hairs on their legs and the brain that falls out of one in episode 2. Not the best example in the world, but the game is full of better ones. 

I know that in Half-life 2 it's almost like retconning. Yes, Breen, you remember your director, right Gordon? Oh, and Kleiner and Eli and don't forget Magnusson. He still doesn't forgive you for that Casserole incident. That last one is actually pretty good because it remembers that you remember having the choice in the first game to do that, and you probably did. It's a cool nod. But I understand if in 2004 someone who played the first game was just confused about who all these people are. I think despite them not really being defined characters or characters at all in the first game, I really think their addition in the sequel makes the story. I love every single one of them. Even Magnusson by the end of episode 2. 

Barney, Keliner, Alyx, Eli, Dog... They all give you a reason to truly care about what you are doing in the story. Without any of these characters you probably wouldn't care that much and I think Half-life 2 would be considered generally a bit worse than the original. Half-life 1 was a lot better in gameplay in my opinion. The AI of the marines is second to none. The combine can't really compete with them in gameplay. But they do in terms of visual design and story. 

The gameplay is fantastic still in this game, even if it doesn't quite compare to its ancestor. Half-life 1 gave you such an array of unique weapons that throughout the whole game still served a purpose. In Half-life 2, for the most part, there's at least 2 weapons that go obsolete. The crowbar and the first assault rifle.  There's no need for the crow bar once you get the gravity gun and the only reason you would use the assault rifle over the pulse rifle would be to use the grenade alt fire. 

Moreover, I do sort of miss the cool and crazy alien and scientific weapons in the first game, though I completely understand for story purposes why those are not there. Plus, I think the gravity gun completely makes up for it and bug bait is cool for nova prospekt. 

Also on gameplay, people seem to think that the enemy variety in the first game beats out the enemy variety in the second. I can understand that completely. I do wonder where the Houndais and the Bull squids went. But I think the combine, despite being a tad too easy to fight compared to marines, are a fantastic representation of what society is now. They help emphasise the hopeless dystopia that humanity is in now due to the 7 hour war. They are faceless people who beat and kill other humans because that's the most power you can obtain as a human in this society. At least the combine soldiers are... Probably should have said that first. Of course, the combine as a whole are aliens that go to planets, drain their resources and take parts of their technology and adapt it to themselves. They are universal colonisers. 

Among the combine there's also some other interesting enemies such as the ant lions, their acid spitting cousins, their rhino looking mothers, the new varieties of head crabs that result in different effects to you as well as different transformations, the hunters, the gunships and the striders. I'm sure if we got episode 3 we could have also added Combine advisor grubs. Sadly we'll never truly know. 

The new zombie types help make the Ravenholm chapter. If it was only the original zombie and head crab type I think it would not be as scary as it is. I love the zombie that has 4-5 black head crabs on his back that just tanks damage, and the ones with no skin that chase you like a dog chasing a car. They make that chapter a lot more intense.

Without the ant lions, 4 of the chapters of the first Half-life 2 would be a lot more empty and uneventful. The rhinos add for a good challenge and, while you may hate the normal ant lions at the start, as soon as you get bug bait they instantly become your brothers in combat. I think that's cool as shit :)
They're also a huge part in Episode 2 as you go through the caves for the larve and they get a couple new enemy types and a bit of lore. Like that they have ties with Vortigaunts because the Vortigaunts are known for ant lion husbandry. 

Every single enemy helps form the identity of the chapters they are in. They all do those jobs incredibly well. Down to the choppers that always give you this anxiety of "I gotta get the hell out of here" while also giving you that thrill of being a badass who's jumping ramps while avoiding bullets, mines and rockets. Water hazard is underrated. 

I could ramble hours upon hours about this game. And, I kinda want to, I don't think I've met that many people who have delved into the world of Half-life and not been deeply interested in it. Its lore is so vast while keeping so many secrets. I still am blown away that this shares a world with portal. 

But I shouldn't write for days on end and you shouldn't read a review for a game you already know is magnificent for days on end. Anyway, thanks for reading :)

Revisiting this game for the 20th anniversary and I am impressed by how well it has aged, and the fact that it still does things that modern shooters overlook. Playing it again after all this time made me appreciate it even more than my first outing. The environmental storytelling, experimental approach to teaching you the game mechanics, clever puzzles and level design really showcase how far ahead of the curve the developers at Valve were at the time. The 20th anniversary update wraps the main game and the episodes into a single launcher and fixes some long standing bugs, making it the best way to experience this classic. I'm looking forward to trying it out again when the RTX mod is released. This is still an absolute masterclass and an icon in the action genre. 10/10.

[h1]Half-Life 2[/h1]
[h3][Overview][/h3]
Half-Life 2 doesn't need much introduction. It's one of the most influential, iconic, and beloved video games ever created. It's engine alone is still being used in games to this day in titles like Garry's Mod and Apex Legends.

[h3][The Positives][/h3]
- Incredible gameplay. Very innovative.
- Great, iconic level design.
- Very good story.
- Very immersive.
- Great horror elements.
- Good music/audio design.
- Graphics and art design still holds up very well.
- Solid enemy AI.
- Many interactive objects and physics puzzles. The Ravenholm chapter demonstrates this well.
- Still gets occasional updates and fixes.
- The 20th anniversary update added Episode One and Episode Two into the base game for free.
- Episode Two is great.
- Steam Workshop mod support.

[h3][Mixed][/h3]
- Episode One is just okay.

[h3][The Negatives][/h3]
- Some sections don't hold up the best. The Water Hazard chapter is just okay.
- The games leak before release led to a lot of content being scrapped or changed. This led to some awkward changes but it doesn't really impact the final product too much.
- Contains one of the most notorious unresolved cliffhangers in gaming history.

[h3][Conclusion][/h3]
Half-Life 2 is easily one of the greatest, most influential FPS games of all time. It's innovative design and great gameplay still holds up to this day. Definitely a must play.

We Need More LGBTQIA+ in Half life 2!
Half life has long been praised for its immersive world and diverse characters, but when it comes to LGBTQIA+ representation, the game falls short. While there are occasional references to LGBTQIA+ characters or themes, they are often minimal or stereotypical, and there is a lack of meaningful representation. Adding more LGBTQIA+ characters and storylines would not only reflect the diverse world we live in, but also provide much-needed visibility for a community that has long been underrepresented in mainstream gaming. Representation matters, and it's important for games like Half life 2 - which already explore complex social issues - to include authentic LGBTQIA+ experiences. This would not only enrich the game's narrative depth but also send a powerful message of inclusivity and acceptance to players around the world. In a game that prides itself on pushing boundaries, why not push for greater diversity and acceptance in all its forms?

What has to be said about Half-Life 2? This game is a timeless masterpiece, and no matter how long it's been since I played it, it'll always be one of my favorites when it comes to first-person shooters. I got my Steam account on Christmas of 2012 along with a variety of Valve games, including Half-Life 2. I instantly fell in love with the story, the gameplay, the music, the graphics... just about every part of it.

Fast forward to now, and it's been over a decade since I first got Steam, and it still holds a place in my heart as one of my favorites. It never seems to age poorly for me, and I only find myself appreciating it more and more as time goes on. If you're on Steam for the first time, this is an essential!

(Also, I just wanted to say that I played Episodes 1 and 2 when they were standalone games and not merged into the main game. I promise that I didn't cheat the achievements in, I agonized over the 333 antlions and that stupid gnome just like everyone else ;-;)

Half-Life 2 isn't just a game; it's an experience. It's a journey into a world where oppression reigns, and a lone scientist, Gordon Freeman, becomes the unlikely symbol of hope. From the moment you step into the desolate City 17, you're swept away by the game's incredible atmosphere. The oppressive Combine regime, with its towering structures and omnipresent surveillance, creates a sense of constant tension and unease.

But Half-Life 2 is more than just a dystopian setting. It's a story about resistance, about ordinary people finding extraordinary courage in the face of overwhelming odds. The characters, from the gruff but loyal Barney Calhoun to the enigmatic Alyx Vance, are unforgettable. Their struggles and triumphs resonate deeply, making you truly care about their fate.

The gameplay is equally captivating. The game's innovative physics engine allows you to interact with the environment in ways never seen before. You can use gravity guns to manipulate objects, solve intricate puzzles, and even launch enemies into the air. The combat is thrilling, blending strategic thinking with adrenaline-pumping action.

Half-Life 2's world is a masterpiece of environmental storytelling. Each location, from the eerie canals of Ravenholm to the sprawling industrial complexes of Nova Prospekt, is meticulously designed to create a unique atmosphere. The game's sound design is equally impressive, with chilling ambient sounds and a haunting soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's mood.
A must, regardless of your preferred genre.

Even fifteen years after its launch, Half Life 2 remains one of the most gripping, thrilling, well written, expertly designed shooters ever. Marc Laidlaw's fascinating sci-fi writing style and Viktor Antonov's superb art design are brought to life with the historically awesome physics engine. The ease with which one slips into the role of Gordon Freeman is just as immediate today as it was when I first played it. HL2 boasts a massive story with great character work, a wide armoury of well-balanced weapons to fight with, and a truly expansive set of environments and locales. 

With the release of MMod, a fan-created mod that expands the gunplay and improves graphics and combat, the staying power of HL2 and its episodes was reinforced for the modern era. I recommend installing it (in fact, it's probably good enough for Valve to add it in as an official optional feature.) 

There's really not much more to say about Half-Life 2. Long been a favourite for me, and for many others. Deserving of all the praise it has recieved and much more.

[b]🎮 Half-Life 2: A Revolutionary Masterpiece of Gaming 🏆[/b]
[i]Half-Life 2[/i], released in 2004, is not merely a video game—it's a [b]revolution[/b] in storytelling, gameplay, and world-building that set the [b]benchmark[/b] for an entire generation. Developed by [b]Valve Corporation[/b], this first-person shooter is a [b]masterpiece[/b] that continues to leave an indelible mark on the industry and [b]gaming culture[/b]. Here's why [i]Half-Life 2[/i] is hailed as one of the greatest games of all time:
[hr][/hr]
[h3][b]🌍 A World That Lives and Breathes[/b][/h3]
The narrative of [i]Half-Life 2[/i] is a [b]crowning achievement[/b] in the realm of interactive storytelling. Set against the backdrop of a dystopian Earth overrun by an alien [b]regime[/b], the game crafts an unforgettable tale of [b]resistance[/b]. As [b]Gordon Freeman[/b], the silent protagonist, players become the face of the rebellion, tasked with overthrowing the [b]Combine[/b].
From the decaying streets of [b]City 17[/b] to the enigmatic [b]Combine Citadel[/b], every environment is [b]meticulously crafted[/b], drawing players into a world that feels [b]alive[/b] and [b]tangible[/b] 🌆💥. The attention to [b]detail[/b] in both the environments and the characters makes the experience feel as though it is unfolding in a living, breathing dystopia.
[hr][/hr]
[h3][b]💡 Groundbreaking Gameplay and Innovation[/b][/h3]
In terms of [b]gameplay[/b], [i]Half-Life 2[/i] is a [b]tour de force[/b] of [b]innovation[/b] 🎮💡. The introduction of the [b]Gravity Gun[/b], a revolutionary tool that allows players to manipulate the world around them, opens up a world of [b]new possibilities[/b] in [b]combat[/b] and [b]puzzle-solving[/b] 🔧⚙️. The [b]seamless integration[/b] of action, exploration, and storytelling keeps you [b]engaged[/b] without the need for frequent cutscenes.
Each level encourages [b]creative thinking[/b] and [b]adaptation[/b], using the environment and the tools at your disposal to [b]solve problems[/b] and confront enemies 🧠🔫. Whether you're [b]pushing[/b] a car to block incoming fire or [b]launching barrels[/b] at foes, [i]Half-Life 2[/i] constantly challenges you to think outside the box.
[hr][/hr]
[h3][b]🌌 Physics and Detail Beyond Compare[/b][/h3]
The attention to [b]detail[/b] is nothing short of [b]astonishing[/b] 🌟. The [b]physics engine[/b], even by today’s standards, remains [b]unparalleled[/b], allowing for [b]realistic[/b] interactions with objects in the environment. Each bullet fired, each object moved, and each [b]falling crate[/b] adds layers of [b]dynamic realism[/b] to the gameplay 🔬🎯.
From high-speed [b]vehicular chases[/b] to [b]heart-pounding[/b] battles against grotesque creatures from another world, [i]Half-Life 2[/i] serves up some of the most [b]adrenaline-pumping[/b] moments in gaming history 🏎️💥. Every encounter feels [b]dynamic[/b] and [b]unique[/b], thanks to the game’s immersive physics engine and its commitment to giving players the freedom to [b]interact[/b] with the environment.
[hr][/hr]
[h3][b]🔨 The Source Engine: A New Era[/b][/h3]
But [i]Half-Life 2[/i] is not just a triumph in gameplay and story—it's also a [b]technical revolution[/b]. With the introduction of the [b]Source engine[/b], Valve forever changed the landscape of gaming 🖥️🎮. The engine powered not only the game’s [b]visuals[/b] and [b]physics[/b] but also spawned an [b]active modding community[/b] 🛠️. Countless mods, custom maps, and multiplayer experiences emerged, extending the game's [b]lifespan[/b] and ensuring its place in the [b]gaming canon[/b].
[hr][/hr]
[h3][b]🎨 A Timeless Piece of Art[/b][/h3]
In conclusion, [i]Half-Life 2[/i] is not just a game; it is a [b]piece of art[/b] 🎨. Its flawless blend of [b]storytelling[/b], [b]gameplay[/b], and [b]technical brilliance[/b] created a legacy that few games have ever come close to matching. Even [b]years[/b] after its release, the game remains [b]timeless[/b], [b]relevant[/b], and an essential experience for every gaming enthusiast.
If you haven’t experienced [i]Half-Life 2[/i] yet, consider this your [b]invitation[/b] to immerse yourself in one of the most important games in the history of the medium 🔑🌌.
[hr][/hr]
[h3][b]Rating: 10/10 ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐[/b][/h3]

Replaying for the first time in almost ten years, 8 playthroughs total. Two new insights I gained on this playthrough (spoilers):

- I always found the singing vortiguant listened to him sing, then carried on. I never knew he had so much incredible dialogue upon clicking. I spent 5 minutes just listening to him and the profound insights into what gordon freeman truly stands for. An incredible little moment among so many others.

- Returning to city 17 after nova prospekt is terrifying. It genuinely feels like war. My heart was constantly racing as I had to overcome what felt like genuinely impossible odds. Back pressed against a pillar, licking my lips as I stared at a rocket supply box which in that moment felt like the most beautiful thing I’d ever seen. Though it was only a foot away, it might as well have been 100 with the giant strider lighting up the area in between. 

Turning in all directions as the combine destroy the ground beneath me in a parking deck, frantically diving for cover and killing as many as I can. 

Seeing the poor unfortunate rebels get eviscerated and watching their bodies smack down beside me like a wet towel. I felt the revolution in City 17 that day and I’ll never forget it. 

- Touching on the first point, but I always wonder whats going through freemans mind. As he dangles helplessly in front of Dr. Breen who in turn dangles a horrifying proposition in front of him: Betray his comrades, and become the face of the combine. On the surface it seems obvious, of course he wouldn’t. But then I remember the end of Half life 1, where he was given a similar ultimatum. A choice to live in servitude of the unknown, or die, free. He made his choice. I wonder… if Mossman hadnt acted as she did and gordon had time to think, would he still have that same resolve? Or maybe his development over the course of the game is gaining exactly that. Going from a scared civilian, to a hero who carries the world on his shoulders. And after carrying it for so long, now has the strength to choose death as a free man. Perhaps the greatest beauty of the narrative is that we may never truly know.

Welp, look who has 60x more hours on HL2 than he should have just because his dummy computer somehow lags less on the internet when a game is running, That's right, me



Half Life games are something that is hard to really capture, they don't have anything special in core, perhaps 2 has the gravity gun, but that's still mostly a cool addition and not really a core feature so many popular games that stand out have. Instead, half life is innovation, every title that came out was a big step in videogames as a whole. Half Life 1 introduced the concept that FPS games can have a story and a lot more to them than just run and gun, Half Life 2 pushed hard on graphics, physics and everything basically, and Alyx is a testament to how much potential VR games have.

Something to note is, half life 2 is a bit odd. Feels like they pushed tech over gameplay. So while it's still good, it just falls a bit short from half life 1. Enemy variety is much smaller and while there aren't enemies that appear once and never again ( 3 ceiling turrets types in Half Life 1, and so many other enemies I remember) it can make the game feel a little more... stale, combine barely shows any new tricks. And any other enemies are basically just zombies, faster zombies, headcrabs, faster headcrabs, cool poison headcrabs with a clevel reverse poison mechanic that are an exception, but still not enough to give much variety. And antlions which have a way to avoid (a car, or platforming) and act more like a punishment for not playing the intended way. 

What HL2 does have is a much better handcrafted experience, while you do go on a car trip for 1.5 hours where barely anything happens, the game switches it's themes a lot and it managed to almost never get stale like a long fun carefully made experience. Half Life 1 can feel like a fever dream with the odd maybe believable but often random places you go, you get to the surface, back to the facility through a vent, into a reactor core, then a random tentacle boss, then a mine under it, then trainstation, then... it's hard to keep track of, but I do remember every chapter in HalfLife 2 because of the bigger emphasis on quality over quantity, while Surface Tension is loved by many in half life 1, and I liked the chapter too, but jeez it's so loooooong, it's a big reason why everyone dislikes the finale, because the game is just dragging out at this point. And while half life 2 (excluding episodes) does end a bit abruptly, it's a roller coaster of fun and well executed ideas in a (almost) perfect flow. 

An amazing one time experience in every way, perhaps a little too small gun variety because it takes a backseat to using enviroment to kill enemies, you find the last gun before halfway through the game
